ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Edmondia elongata, collected from the Ford Formation (reef facies) of Late Permian, Zechstein (Durham Province), EZ1 age from Tunstall Hill, Sunderland, Tyne and Wear (NE England). Collected by James Walter Kirkby.
NarNarrative: This bivalve (meaning two valves or shells), lived on a reef, a community teeming with life, forming a ridge close to the coastline, in the Zechstein Sea, 250 million years ago. This Sea stretched from what is now north east England over to Northern Germany and Poland. Edmondia elongata lived in a shallow burrow in the seabed, and fed on tiny animals and plants in the sea water.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, Tyne and Wear (NE England), Sunderland, Tunstall Hill

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Wilkingia elegans, collected from the Ford Formation (reef facies) of Late Permian, Zechstein (Durham Province), EZ1 age from Tunstall Hill, Sunderland, Tyne and Wear (NE England). Collected by James Walter Kirkby.
NarNarrative: Wilkingia elegans was a bivalve (two shells or valves) that lived on a reef (an under water ridge that was teeming with life) in the warm Zechstein Sea 250 million years ago. This bivalve would probably have lived with its shells partially buried in the seabed, feeding on tiny food particles in the water.
ComName_tab: wilkingia elegans (king), Bivalve Pholadomyoida Pholadomyacea Pholadomyida

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil gastropod, Pleurotomaria similis, collected from the Upper Lias of Early Jurassic age from Blockley, Gloucestershire (SW England). Collected by D.M. Lumsden.
NarNarrative: Pleurotomaria is a sea snail (marine gastropod). It probably fed on algae on the sea floor, where the water was shallow, and well lit. Much of the shell has been worn away by the action of weather, or river water, after it became a fossil.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil gastropod, Patella rugosa, collected from the Great Oolite of Middle Jurassic, Bathonian age from Minchinhampton, Gloucestershire (SW England).
NarNarrative: Patella rugosa probably got its name from its similarity to the human kneecap bone, which is called a patella. It is a mollusc that lived on rocks at the edge of the sea. It attached itself to the rocks with a strong muscle (foot), like today's limpets that live in rock pools.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca

SciName: Cephalopoda & Goniatites : : : :

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil gastropod, Athleta luctator, collected from the Barton Group (Barton Beds ?) of Tertiary, Late Eocene, Lutetian - Bartonian age from Barton, Bournemouth, Hampshire (SE England).
NarNarrative: This thick sea snail shell has a pattern of spiral ridges and vertical ribs on the outside. Athleta lived in warm subtropical shallow coastal waters in a community made up mainly of gastropods and bivalves. It was a predator and a scavenger that fed on live molluscs, dead animals and plants on the sea floor. The snail shell was one of the first British fossils to be given a scientific name using the new Linnean classification system (using a Latin genus and species name) by Daniel Solander in 1766.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, Hampshire (SE England), Bournemouth (nr.), Barton (?)

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil echinoid (heart urchin), Micraster elegans, collected from the Tardefurcata Zone = Dispar Zone, Duck Creek Formation of Early Cretaceous, Albian age from Tarrant County, Texas, USA. Collected by David M. Lumsden.
NarNarrative: The smooth test (shell) and shape of this echinoid (sea urchin) shows that it was able to burrow in soft seabeds. When alive, the shell was covered with skin and bristle-like spines that helped the echinoid burrow. Micraster was a deposit feeder, which means it took food particles from the sediment (sand and muds) that it ate. Its mouth is on the flattened lower surface. It is often known as a heart urchin because of its shape.
SciName: Echinoidea : : : : Echinodermata

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Cardium Parkinsoni, collected from the Red Crag of Quaternary, Early Pleistocene age from Walton-on-the-Naze, Essex (SE England). Collected by William K. Loftus.
NarNarrative: The outside of this round single cockle shell is covered with broad ribs (ridges) separated by narrow furrows (troughs). Cerastoderma lived in a vertical position in a shallow burrow on the surface of sandy seabeds. It fed on tiny food particles that it filtered out of sea water. When the animal died the two valves usually separated. Accumulations of single shells and gravel made up of shells often occur in water depths up to 50m, including the area between high and low tide (intertidal zone), where the bivalve lived.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, Essex (SE England), Felixtowe (nr.), Walton on the Naze

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil ammonite, unidentified, collected from unspecified rocks.
NarNarrative: This ammonite has been sliced into two pieces and polished, so that the inside of the fossil can be seen. Ammonites were sea creatures, similar to the modern nautilus that lives in the Pacific Ocean. They became extinct (died out) at the same time as the dinosaurs, 65 million years ago. Ammonites had coiled shells that were divided into chambers by walls inside the shell. In this example, the chambers are filled with crystals of the mineral calcite.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Ammonoidea : : : Cephalopoda : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Trilobite
ComName_tab: , calymene blumenbachi (brongniart 1822), Animalia Invertebrata Arthropoda Trilobita
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Arthropoda & Trilobita : : : :
LocalSum: UK, England, West Midlands (Midland England), Dudley, Wren's Nest

ColPhysicalDescription: Trace fossil.
ComName_tab: , cruziana sp., Animalia Invertebrata Arthropoda Trilobita
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Arthropoda & Trilobita : : : :

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil crinoid (Sea Lily), Marsupites sp., collected from the Marsupites Zone, Chalk Formation of Late Cretaceous, Senonian (?), Santonian (?) age.
NarNarrative: This crinoid calyx (sea lily cup) is made up of three rows of five-sided plates which are made of the mineral calcite. Unlike most fossil crinoids, it did not have a stem fixing it to the sea floor. Like most present day crinoids it simply rested on the sea floor. The short, slender branching arms that it used to collect its food particles from the sea water are rarely found as fossils. The crinoid lived in quiet, shallow waters.
SciName: Crinoidea : : : : Echinodermata

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil echinoid (sea urchin), Cidaris sp., collected from the Chalk Formation of Late Cretaceous age.
NarNarrative: Animals sometimes lose parts of their bodies when they are alive or break up into separate pieces after they die. Such fragments are often found in the fossil record. Sea urchin spines are a very good example of this. The shape and the patterns on the spines are often distinctive enough to match them to a particular sea urchin species. Echinoids are useful environmental indicators because they live in open seas where the salinity (water salt content) is normal.
SciName: Echinoidea : : : : Echinodermata

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil brachiopod, Terebratula grandis, collected from the Red Crag of Quaternary, Early Pleistocene age from Suffolk (SE England). Collected by William K. Loftus.
NarNarrative: In life, this brachiopod was attached to the sea floor by a pedicle (fleshy stalk) that grew through the hole in the point of the larger shell. Terebratula usually lived in gravel communities where the water was up to 50m deep. It fed on tiny food particles that it filtered out of the water. The species grew up to 11cm long in its 5 to 7 year life span and is the largest terebratulid brachiopod ever known.
ComName_tab: Lamp Shell, terebratula grandis (blumenbach), Animalia Invertebrata Brachipoda Articulata Terebratulida
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Brachipoda & Articulata & Terebratulida : : : :

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil gastropod (snail), Pleurotomaria sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Quaternary, Pleistocene age from Coral Bay, Cyprus. Collected by David M. Lumsden.
NarNarrative: The original low-angled cone-shaped shell of this sea snail has a pattern of vertical ribs and spiral cords (rope-like pattern). The whorls (coils) of the shell increase in size towards the rounded opening in the shell where the snail could withdraw its soft body for protection. There is a groove in the shell known as a 'slit band' that formed a channel to carry water pumped out of the body away from the head region of the snail.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Aquipecten opercularis, collected from the Clyde Beds of Quaternary, Late Pleistocene, Late Devensian, Windermere Interstadial age from Clyde, Scotland.
NarNarrative: The round, lightweight shell has prominent 'wings' next to the hinge line (the hinge where the two shells met) and a pattern of radiating ribs. Aequipecten lived freely on the surface of the seabed. A ligament on the hinge allowed the shells to open at an angle of up to 30? whilst it fed on food particles that it filtered out of the water. It could also swim by 'clapping' its valves together but usually only did so for short distances to escape from predators.
GeoAge: Quaternary & Pleistocene (Late) & Devensian (Late) & Windermere Interstadial / 10,200 - 13,780 years
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil gastropod (snail), Searlesia costifera, collected from the Red Crag of Quaternary, Early Pleistocene age from Walton-on-the-Naze, Essex (SE England). Collected by William K. Loftus.
NarNarrative: The original shells of these spindle-shaped gastropods have a pattern of fine spiral cords (rope-like pattern) and broad rounded vertical ribs. The whorls (coils) of the shell increase in size towards the opening into which the snail could withdraw its soft body for protection. The thick shell shows that Searlesia lived in high-energy coastal waters up to 15m deep, the shell protecting the animal from the rough water. It was a predator that fed on bivalves and other molluscs that lived in the muddy sand on the sea floor.
ComName_tab: Snail, searcesia costifera (s. v. wood), Gastropod
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, Essex (SE England), Felixtowe (nr.), Walton on the Naze

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil gastropod (snail), Neptunea despecta decemostata, collected from the Red Crag of Quaternary, Early Pleistocene age from Walton-on-the-Naze, Essex (SE England). Collected by William K. Loftus.
NarNarrative: These spindle-shaped sea snails have a pattern of spiral ridges on their shells as well as growth lines. The whorls (coils) of the shell increase in size towards the opening into which the snail could withdraw its soft body for protection. Neptunea lived in high-energy coastal environments on sandy seabeds below the intertidal zone (the area between high and low tide) in water up to 15m deep. It was a predator that fed on worms and bivalves.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, Essex (SE England), Felixtowe (nr.), Walton on the Naze

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimens are all juveniles less than 5mm.
ComName_tab: Lamp Shell, dielasma elongatum (?), Brachiopod Articulata
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Brachiopoda & Articulata : : : Articulata : Brachiopoda

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Liostrea hisingeri, collected from unspecified rocks of Late Triassic, Rhaetic age. Collected by Emma Smith.
NarNarrative: Liostrea hisingeri was a small oyster, a type of bivalve (meaning two shells or valves). Modern oysters need a stable environment, and are often common where burrowing bivalves are not found. Shallow water and a muddy sea floor are also conditions that oysters prefer. There are three fossilised Liostrea shells on this piece of rock.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Monotis decussata, collected from the Westbury Beds (?) of Late Triassic, Rhaetic age from Westbury-on-Severn (river section), Gloucestershire (SW England). Collected by the Rev. P. Brodie.
NarNarrative: The surface of this piece of rock is covered with the very small shells of Monotis decussata, a shellfish that was common during the late Triassic. Monotis has a thin shell. Recent research suggests that it was a planktonic or pseudo-planktonic animal, meaning that it spent its life floating in the water, rather than living on or burrowing in the seabed. If Monotis was planktonic, the reason for so many of these tiny shells being grouped together like this is that they were swept together by currents after death.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, Gloucestershire (SW England), Westbury-on-Severn (river section)

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil crinoid (Sea Lily), Encrinus lilliformis, collected from the Muschelkalk (?) of Middle Triassic (?) age. Complete calyx with arms.
NarNarrative: This fossil is the cup and the arms of the crinoid (sea lily) Encrinus lilliformis. The long, flexible 'stem', which would have connected the crinoid to the sea floor is missing from this fossil. Crinoids look like plants, but they are animals, related to sea urchins and starfish. Crinoids ate tiny creatures that floated in the sea water.
SciName: Crinoidea : : : : Echinodermata

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil coral, Thecosmilia annularis, collected from the Corallian Beds of Late Jurassic, Oxfordian age from Steeple Ashton, Wiltshire (SW England). Collected by D.M. Lumsden.
NarNarrative: Thecosmilia is a colonial coral which means it is actually several small coral animals, that look a bit like tiny sea anemones, and have built homes together. The 'skeletons' of modern corals (the hard tubes in which the animals live), are often used as ornaments by collector's today. It is not uncommon to see these on sale in shops in seaside resorts. A good place to see living corals is the Great Barrier Reef, off the coast of Australia.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata &  Anthozoa : : : : Coelenterata
LocalSum: UK, England, Wiltshire (SW England), Steeple Ashton

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimens of fossil faecal pellets (coprolites or droppings), collected from the Lias of Early Jurassic age from North Yorkshire (NE England). Collected by Albany Hancock (et.al.).
NarNarrative: Coprolites are the fossilised droppings of animals. If you look closely, you can see that some of the coprolites have a slightly coiled or spiral shape. These coprolites are from rocks of Jurassic age along the Yorkshire coast. They are probably from fish, or the larger marine reptiles, such as ichthyosaurs and plesiosaurs that were alive at the same time as the dinosaurs.

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil brachiopod, (Lamp Shell), Spirifer striatus, collected from the Carboniferous Limestone of Early Carboniferous, Dinantian (?), Visean (?) age. Collected by N.C. Cookson, 1874. Single shell with some damage adjoining hinge line.
NarNarrative: Spirifer is a common Carboniferous brachiopod (lamp shell) that is easily recognised by its long straight hinge line (the line between the shells at the hinge) and large fold along the midline of its shell. Spirifer lived attached to the sea floor by a fleshy stalk known as a pedicle. It lived in clear waters in the deeper parts of warm, shallow, tropical seas and is often found in reef communities. It fed on small particles of food that it filtered out of the water.
ComName_tab: Lamp Shell, spirifer striatus (?) (martin), Brachiopod Articulata
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Brachiopoda & Articulata : : : Articulata : Brachiopoda

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Plagiostoma striata, collected from the Muschelkalk of Middle Triassic age from Heidelberg, Germany. Collected by W.K. Loftus.
NarNarrative: Plagiostoma striata is similar to the modern oyster. It has a shell with many fine ribs (ridges), a bit like modern cockle shells, but flatter. Bivalves (sea shells) like this one are the type of fossil most commonly found in German rocks of this type and age.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil belemnite, Cylindroteuthis sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Jurassic age.
NarNarrative: Belemnites were similar to the modern squid, but died out (became extinct), at the same time as the dinosaurs, 65 million years ago. This fossil, which looks a bit like a large bullet, was the internal 'skeleton' of the animal, and it was covered by soft fleshy material. The belemnite had tentacles for catching its prey. Belemnites were eaten by marine reptiles. Their remains have been found in the stomachs of ichthyosaurs.
ComName_tab: , cylindroteuthis sp. (?), Animalia Invertebrata Mollusca Cephalopoda Belemnoidea
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Belemnoidea : : : :

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bryozoan (sea mat or moss animal), Acanthocladia anceps, collected from the Ford Formation (reef facies) of Late Permian, Zechstein (Durham Province), EZ1 age from Tunstall Hill (?), Sunderland, Tyne and Wear (NE England). Collected by James Walter Kirkby. Reef coquina with bivalves and other bryozoan including Fenestella retiformis.
NarNarrative: Acanthocladia anceps was a bryozoan or moss animal that lived on a reef (a ridge made up of living animals and the remains of dead animals under the water). It lived in the Zechstein Sea in the Sunderland area 250 million years ago. This particular bryozoan looked a bit like a modern coral, with many branches. The tiny animals (known as zooids) looked a bit like small sea anemones, and lived in little holes in the branching structure called cysts. They fed on tiny plants and animals that lived in the sea water.
ComName_tab: Sea Mat (or Moss Animal), acanthocladia anceps (schlotheim), Animalia Invertebrata Bryozoa Stenolaemata Cyclostomata
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Bryozoa & Stenolaemata & Cyclostomata : : : :
LocalSum: UK, England, Tyne and Wear (NE England), Sunderland, Tunstall Hill

ColPhysicalDescription: Stem or radial arm segment.
SciName: Crinoidea : : : : Echinodermata
LocalSum: UK, England, Tyne and Wear (NE England), Sunderland, Tunstall Hill

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil crustacean (lobster), a Mud Lobster, Thalassina squamifera, collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary (?) age.
NarNarrative: This fossil lobster has powerful digging claws and a very slender abdomen (lower body). Mud lobsters are common today in tropical regions along muddy shorelines and in mangrove swamps. They feed on the organic particles in the mud and build volcano-like mounds over a metre high. They are edible but have a muddy flavour and are not popular. In some areas they are pests because their burrowing affects agriculture and causes river banks and flood defences to collapse.
ComName_tab: Mud Lobster, thalassina squamifera, Animalia Invertebrata Arthropoda Crustacea
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Arthropoda & Crustacea : : : :

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Gryphaea arcuata Lamarck, collected from Lower Lias rocks of Early Jurassic age.
NarNarrative: The shells of Gryphaea arcuata are very common in rocks of Lower Lias age, around 200 million years ago. These shells are related to the modern oyster, clams and mussels. The distinctive curved shape and wrinkled surface of the shells gives them the name of 'devil's toenails'.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil nautiloid, Peripetoceras freieslebeni, collected from the Ford Formation (reef facies) of Late Permian, Zechstein (Durham Province), EZ1 age from Sunderland (?), Tyne and Wear (NE England).
NarNarrative: Peripetoceras freieslebeni was similar to Nautilus which lives in the Pacific Ocean. In north east England, during the Permian period, there was a reef made of fan-shaped bryozoans (moss animals). You can see part of this reef at Tunstall Hill near Sunderland. Approximately 250 million years ago, Sunderland was only 12 degrees North of the Equator (today, as a result of continental drift, it is nearer 55 degrees North), so the sea was very warm. Peripetoceras freieslebeni was one of the creatures that lived in this reef.
ComName_tab: , peripetoceras freieslebeni (geinitz), Animalia Invertebrata Mollusca Cephalopoda Nautiloidea
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Nautiloidea : : : :
LocalSum: UK, England, Tyne and Wear (NE England), Sunderland (?)

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossiliferous limestone with brachiopods, lamp shell, unidentified, collected from unspecified rocks of Early (?) Carboniferous age.
NarNarrative: This piece of limestone contains several brachiopods (lamp shells). Dark grey to black limestones of Carboniferous age are quite common in north east England. This is similar to the Frosterley Marble, which is a black limestone containing white fossilised corals. You will usually find this type of limestone, containing white fossils, on the beaches of Northumberland, where it is very common.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Brachiopoda & Articulata : : : Articulata : Brachiopoda

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimens of fossil crinoid, sea lily stems, St Cuthbert's Beads, collected from unspecified rocks of Carboniferous age.
NarNarrative: These small, bead-like fossils are parts of the broken-up stems of crinoids (sea lilies), known as ossicles. They are also called St. Cuthbert's beads in many parts of England. St. Cuthbert spent many years on Lindisfarne (Holy Island), off the coast of north Northumberland. These fossils are found on the beach opposite St. Cuthbert's Isle. The legend of threading the fossils as rosary beads comes from Lindisfarne.
ComName_tab: Sea Lily, St Cuthbert's Beads, Crinoidea
SciName: Crinoidea : : : : Echinodermata

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil ammonite, unidentified, collected from unspecified rocks of Jurassic (?) age.
NarNarrative: This ammonite has been cut in half and polished, so that you can see what the inside of the shell looks like. The palest areas show the outline of the shell. The brown areas are crystals, probably of the mineral calcite, which have grown over the surfaces of the shell, filling in the hollow spaces which are also known as chambers. Ammonites ate small sea creatures. They moved around using a jet propulsion system, which moved the ammonite backwards. The chambers were filled with gas, which helped the ammonite float under the water.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Ammonoidea : : : Cephalopoda : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil coral, Lithostrotion sp., collected from the Carboniferous Limestone of Early (?) Carboniferous age.
NarNarrative: This pebble of black limestone contains the fossilised remains (the long thin white markings), of the coral Lithostrotion. Pebbles like these are common on the beaches of north east England. The limestone becomes smoothed, when the sea rolls the pebbles against each other on the beaches.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata &  Anthozoa : : : : Coelenterata

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Hiatella crafisa, collected from unspecified rocks of Quaternary (?) age.
NarNarrative: This bivalve has two equally sized thick shells covered with evenly space lamellae (ridges). The nature of the seabed determines the way in which these shellfish lived. Those that settle on rocky seabeds live in holes that they drill, whilst those that settle on soft sediment attach themselves to the seabed with thread like hairs. Living relatives are filter feeders that live on the lower shore and coastal waters up to 50m deep in cool temperate and cold polar seas.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil coral, Balanophyllia sp., collected from the Red Crag (?) of Quaternary (?), Early Pleistocene age.
NarNarrative: This colonial (a group living together) coral skeleton shows three complete corallites (hard tubes) that provided protection for the soft-bodied coral polyp, which looked like a sea anemone The coral fed by collecting food particles out of sea water in its tentacles. Balanophyllia usually occurs in warm shallow water communities that are dominated by bivalves and gastropods, in 10 to 15m deep water.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata &  Anthozoa : : : : Coelenterata

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil brachiopod, , Schellwienella crenistria, collected from the Upper Limestone Group of Early Carboniferous, Namurian, Pendleian age from Shaftoe Crags, Northumberland (NE England).
NarNarrative: The shells of this brachiopod are gently convex (outward curving). The umbo (pointed end) of one shell was cemented (glued) to the sea floor so that the rounded edge of the shell faced upwards. Schellwienella lived in clear, warm shallow, tropical seas with sandy floors. Fossils are often found in sandstone, like this specimen, as well as limestone. Like all brachiopods it fed on food particles that it filtered out of the water.
ComName_tab: Lamp Shell, schellwienella crenistria (phillips), Brachiopod Articulata
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Brachiopoda & Articulata : : : Articulata : Brachiopoda
LocalSum: UK, England, Northumberland (NE England), Shaftoe Crags

ColPhysicalDescription: Dictyoclostus semireticulatus, collected from unspecified rocks of Carboniferous age.
NarNarrative: This brachiopod has a ribbed biconvex shell with a distinctive ridge and hollow on the midline. Like most brachiopods Dictyioclostus was attached to the sea floor by a pedicle (fleshy stalk) that grew through a hole on the fold of the larger shell close to the hinge line. It lived on the floor of warm shallow tropical seas and fed on food particles that it filtered out of the water.
ComName_tab: Lamp Shell, dictyoclostus semireticulatus (martin), Animalia Invertebrata Brachiopoda
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Brachiopoda : : : :

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil coral, Dibunophyllum bipartitum, collected from the Great Limestone of Early Carboniferous, Namurian, Pendleian age from ?, Co Durham (NE England). Polished Slab of Frosterley Marble.
NarNarrative: This polished cut section of limestone shows several sections of the solitary (one that doesn't share a skeleton structure with other corals) coral Dibunophyllum that had a curved cone-shaped skeleton. The inside structure of the coral skeleton can be clearly seen with a pattern of the radiating walls (septa) and circular walls (dissepiments). Differences in the patterns of the walls are used to identify different coral species. Like most corals it lived in warm shallow seas near the equator. This piece of limestone is called Frosterley Marble, and is often used as a decorative stone. It can be seen in the huge stone columns in the Chapel of the Nine Alters at Durham Cathedral.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata &  Anthozoa : : : : Coelenterata

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil crustacean (shrimp), Kallidectis richardsoni, collected from unspecified rocks of Carboniferous (?) age.
NarNarrative: This specimen shows the three main parts of the shrimp's soft shell that is made out of chitin, a material similar to finger nails. The head with two antennae and other short appendages is on the right, the thorax (upper body) and several pairs of legs in the centre and the abdomen to the left. Such shrimps lived in fresh and salt water and were probably scavengers that fed on organic debris found on lake and sea floors.
ComName_tab: Shrimp, kallidectis richardsoni, Animalia Invertebrata Arthropoda Crustacea
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Arthropoda & Crustacea : : : :

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil crustacean (shrimp), Beletelson magister, collected from unspecified rocks of Carboniferous (?) age.
NarNarrative: This specimen shows the outline of a shrimp's soft shell, which is made out of chitin, a material similar to finger nails. The head is on the right, the thorax (upper body) with legs in the centre and the abdomen to the left. Such shrimps lived in fresh and salt water and were probably scavengers that fed on organic debris found on lake and sea floors. Chemicals that formed when the shrimp died may have helped form the nodule (lump) in which it is preserved.
ComName_tab: Shrimp, beletelson magister, Animalia Invertebrata Arthropoda Crustacea
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Arthropoda & Crustacea : : : :

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil coral, Dibunophyllum splendens, collected from the Great Scar Limestone Group (?) of Early (?) Carboniferous, Namurian (?) age.
NarNarrative: The specimen is a polished section through the tube-shaped skeleton of the solitary coral Dibunophyllum (one that doesn't share a skeleton structure with other corals) that had a curved cone-shaped skeleton. The structure of the coral skeleton is easy to see with a pattern of long and short septa (walls) around the margin. Differences in the number and patterns of the septa are used to identify different coral species. Like most corals it lived in warm shallow seas near the equator.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata &  Anthozoa : : : : Coelenterata

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil blastoid, Orbitremites norwoodi, collected from unspecified rocks of Early (?) Carboniferous, Mississippian (?) age from Indiana, USA. Collected by David M. Lumsden.
NarNarrative: Blastoids are an extinct group of echinoderms (a group that includes star fish and sea urchins). The bud-shaped calyx (cup) containing the animal's organs is usually all that is found in the fossil record. It was attached to the sea floor, either directly or by a stalk, and had a crown of delicate arms that it used to collect food particles from the sea water. The petal-shaped (abulacral) areas contained a groove that passed the food to the mouth in the centre. Blastoids are most commonly found in shallow water reef communities.
SciName: Blastoidea : : : : Echinodermata

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil asteroid (starfish), Neopalaeaster sp., collected from the Scremerston Coal Group of Early Carboniferous, Dinantian, Visean, Asbian age from Plashetts Quarry, Kielder, Northumberland (NE England).
NarNarrative: The bodies of starfish are flexible and their skeletons consists of many small plates held together by soft tissues. Since soft tissue (flesh) usually rots after death, starfish are not often preserved as fossils. This specimen shows a small starfish preserved on sandstone. Its life-style was probably similar to living starfish that are found in shallow coastal waters. They are predators that feed on other animals such as corals and bivalves.
SciName: Asteroidea : : : : Echinodermata

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil coral, Cyathophyllum sp., collected from the Carboniferous Limestone (?) of Early (?) Carboniferous, Dinantian (?), Visean (?) age from Northumberland (NE England).
NarNarrative: Cyathophyllum is a solitary coral (one that doesn't share a skeleton structure with other corals) that has a cylinder-shaped outer skeleton. This fossil shows sections of many solitary corals that lived close together. The internal structure of the coral skeleton is quite clear. Differences in the patterns of the radiating walls (septa) and circular walls (dissepiments) are used to identify different coral species. Like most corals Cyathophyllum lived on the floor of warm shallow seas near the equator.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata &  Anthozoa : : : : Coelenterata

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil brachiopod, (Lamp Shell), Leptagonia sp., collected from the Carboniferous Limestone of Carboniferous age. Assemblage forming most of rock.
NarNarrative: One shell of this brachiopod
ComName_tab: Lamp Shell, leptagonia sp., Animalia Invertebrata Brachiopoda
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Brachiopoda : : : :

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil coral, a Chain Coral, Halysites sp., collected from the Much Wenlock Limestone Formation of Early Silurian, Wenlock, Homerian age from Wren's Nest, Dudley, West Midlands (Midland England).
NarNarrative: Corals are very common in the Wenlock Limestone and locally form small 'patch' reefs. The common name for this example is 'Chain Coral' as the corallites (each individual section of coral) are joined end to end and look like the links of a chain.
ComName_tab: Chain Coral, halysites sp., Animalia Invertebrata  Anthozoa
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata &  Anthozoa : : : : Coelenterata
LocalSum: UK, England, West Midlands (Midland England), Dudley, Wren's Nest

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil ammonite, collected from unspecified rocks of Jurassic age.
NarNarrative: We don't know where this large ammonite came from. Ammonites this size and larger are found in the Purbeck area of Dorset, on the South coast of England, where big ammonites are often used as garden ornaments. The ammonites found on the North Yorkshire coast are usually much smaller than this one. The closest living relative of the ammonite is the pearly nautilus, that lives in the Pacific Ocean.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Ammonoidea : : : Cephalopoda : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Bakevellia binneyi Brown, collected from the Ford Formation (reef facies) of Late Permian, Zechstein (Durham Province), EZ1 age from Field House Quarry, Ryhope, Tyne and Wear (NE England). Collected by James Walter Kirkby.
NarNarrative: Bakevellia binneyi is a bivalve (two valves or shells). This shellfish lived on the reef, an environment teeming with life, in the Zechstein Sea. It would have lived with its shell partially buried in the seabed, using a byssal attachment (strong thread like fibres) to fasten itself in place. It may also have lived in crevices in the reef.

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil brahiopod, lamp shell, Productus senbaculus, collected from the Redesdale Ironstone, Scremerston Coal Group of Early Carboniferous, Dinantian, Visean, Asbian age from Northumberland (NE England). Collected by Sir W.C. Trevelyan.
NarNarrative: The shells (valves) of Productus are quite different in size and shape. The larger convex (outward curving) shell rested on the sea floor and a smaller flat shell acted like a lid. Productus was an unusual brachiopod because it did not have a pedicle (fleshy stalk) to keep it fixed to the sea floor. Instead it used stubby spines on the outside of the concave shell to keep it in position. The broken ends of these spines can be seen clearly on one specimen
ComName_tab: Lamp Shell, productus senbaculus, Brachiopod Articulata
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Brachiopoda & Articulata : : : Articulata : Brachiopoda

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Sanguinolites costellatus M'Coy, collected from unspecified rocks of Early Carboniferous, Dinantian, Visean, Asbian age from Bellingham, Northumberland (NE England). Collected by William King.
NarNarrative: This bivalve shellfish lived in burrows on the sea floor. It fed on small food particles that it filtered out of the sea water. The bivalve probably died in its burrow because its two shells have remained joined together. Sanguinolites is usually found with other animals that could live in extremely salty (hypersaline) sea water such as that found in coastal lagoons. It is often found with another bivalve called Modiolus.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Showing variation.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil brachiopod Pustula pustulosa, collected from unspecified rocks of Late Carboniferous, Brigantian - Pendleian age from Coppicewood Quarry, Alston, Cumbria (NW England). Collected by A. Blackett.
NarNarrative: The shells of Pustula are quite different in size and shape. It lived partly buried on the sea floor with the larger convex (outward curving) shell facing downwards and had a smaller flat shell acting like a lid. Spines on the outside of the concave shell anchored Pustula in soft sea floors. It lived in areas of the sea where the water was clouded with mud. Like all brachiopods it fed on food particles that it filtered out of the water.
ComName_tab: Lamp Shell, pustula pustulosa (phillips), Brachiopod Articulata
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Brachiopoda & Articulata : : : Articulata : Brachiopoda

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil brachiopod, (Lamp Shell), Productus productus, collected from the Carboniferous Limestone of Early Carboniferous, Dinantian, Visean age from Bowland, Lancashire (NW England).
NarNarrative: The two shells of this brachiopod
ComName_tab: Lamp Shell, productus productus (martin), Brachiopod Articulata
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Brachiopoda & Articulata : : : Articulata : Brachiopoda

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil brachiopod, (Lamp Shell), Gigantoproductus giganteus, collected from the Carboniferous Limestone of Carboniferous, Visean - Namurian age. Collected by Dr G. Storey, 1938.
NarNarrative: As its name suggests this is one of the largest of all brachiopods (lamp shells) and grew up to 35cm wide. It lived partly buried on the sea floor with the convex shell facing downwards. The other shell was flat and acted like a lid. Hollow spines on the outside of the convex shell anchored Gigantoproductus onto soft sea floors. It lived in areas of the sea where the water was clouded with mud and fed on food particles that it filtered out of the water.
ComName_tab: Lamp Shell, gigantoproductus giganteus (j. sowerby), Brachiopod Articulata
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Brachiopoda & Articulata : : : Articulata : Brachiopoda

ColPhysicalDescription: Lamp Shell
ComName_tab: Lamp Shell, gigantoproductus giganteus (j. sowerby), Brachiopod Articulata
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Brachiopoda & Articulata : : : Articulata : Brachiopoda

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil cephalopod, Orthoceras sp., collected from the Carboniferous Limestone of Early Carboniferous, Dinantian, Visean (?) age from Closeburn, Nithsdale, Dumfriesshire (Scotland). Collected by Thomas Sopwith.
NarNarrative: The specimen is part of an orthocone and shows the internal septa (walls) and chambers of the shell. The animal was similar to a squid and lived in the largest last chamber of the shell. Orthocones swam using jet propulsion, forcing water out of its body. It was carnivorous and fed mainly on shrimps, crabs and fish they caught in their tentacles. The specimen was found by the famous eighteenth century Newcastle geologist and mining engineer Thomas Sopwith.
ComName_tab: , orthoceras sp., Animalia Invertebrata Mollusca Cephalopoda Nautiloidea
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Nautiloidea : : : :
LocalSum: UK, Scotland, Dumfries and Galloway (Scotland), Nithsdale, Closeburn

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil coral, Zaphrentis coryophylloides, collected from the Carboniferous Limestone of Early (?) Carboniferous, Dinantian (?), Visean (?) age. Collected by H.B. Brady.
NarNarrative: The cone-shaped skeleton of the solitary coral (one that doesn't share a skeleton structure with other corals) Zaphrentites was attached to the sea floor at the pointed end. The living coral polyp occupied the cup shaped hollow at the wide end of the cone (left-hand image). The polyp looked like a sea anemone with a mouth in the centre of a ring of tentacles that it used to capture small animals as food. Like most corals it lived in warm shallow seas near the equator.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata &  Anthozoa : : : : Coelenterata

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil coral, Lithostrotion martini, collected from the Upper Limestone Group of Early Carboniferous, Namurian age from Scots Gap (railcut near station), Cambo, Northumberland (NE England). Collected by Sir W.C. Trevelyan.
NarNarrative: This fossil shows a section through part of the colonial (living as a group) coral Lithostrotion. The inside structure of the coral skeleton is easy to see. Differences in the patterns of the radiating walls (septa) and circular walls (dissepiments) are used to identify different coral species. Like most corals Lithostrotion lived on the floor of warm shallow seas near the equator.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata &  Anthozoa : : : : Coelenterata
LocalSum: UK, England, Northumberland (NE England), Rothbury, Scots Gap (rail cutting between)

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil brachiopod, (Lamp Shell), unidentified, collected from the Carboniferous Limestone of Early Carboniferous, Dinantian, Visean (?) age. Collected by N.C. Cookson.
NarNarrative: Productids were unusual brachiopod (lamp shells) because they used spines on the outside of their shells to anchor themselves in muddy and sandy sea floors. Most brachiopods have a pedicle (fleshy stalk) to attach themselves to firm sea floors. The spines are fragile and break off the shell easily and are sometimes found as fossils. This specimen shows a collection of spines that have been preserved in mudstone.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Brachiopoda & Articulata : : : Articulata : Brachiopoda

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil coral, a Slipper coral, Calceola sandalina, collected from unspecified rocks of Middle Devonian age from Eifel, Rhine, Germany.
NarNarrative: Calceola sandalina is also known as the slipper coral because it can look like the toe of a slipper. It was a solitary coral (it lived on its own) that is semicircular in section (most solitary corals are circular). Corals were animals that looked a bit like small sea anemones and are called polyps. They lived inside hard structures made of the mineral calcite, which is the part of a coral that is preserved as a fossil. This coral is only found in rocks of Devonian age.
ComName_tab: Slipper Coral, calceola sandalina, Animalia Invertebrata  Anthozoa
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata &  Anthozoa : : : : Coelenterata

NarNarrative: Brachiopods were marine animals with two shells. Strophonella, like most brachiopods, lived attached to the seabed. They fed by filtering microscopic particles of food out of the sea water.
ComName_tab: Lamp Shell, strophonella sp., Brachiopod Articulata

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil trilobite, Angelina sedgwicki Salter, collected from unspecified rocks of Early Ordovician, Late Tremadoc age from Garth (Farm ?), Porthmadoc, Gwynned (Wales). Collected by E.J. Garwood.
NarNarrative: This trilobite is about 490 million years old and lived on the bottom of the sea. When it died, the skeleton was covered in mud and it became fossilised. The mud hardened and became a mudstone. Later, the continents (land masses) on each side of the Ordovician sea slowly moved towards each other so that the sea slowly disappeared. This caused the mudstones of the seabed to be squeezed and heated and turned into a much harder rock called a slate. This is why the trilobite looks squashed.
ComName_tab: , angelina sedgwickii (salter), Animalia Invertebrata Arthropoda Trilobita
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Arthropoda & Trilobita : : : :

ColPhysicalDescription: Distorted trilobite on slate slab, part and counterpart.  The large piece has been on display.

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil graptolite, Didymograptus patulus, collected from the Skiddaw Group of Early Ordovician, Arenig (?) age from Randale Beck (?), Cumbria (NW England). Collected by John Jeffrey, 1918.
NarNarrative: At first glance this fossil looks like a small saw blade in black slate! In fact it is part of the skeleton of an extinct fossil animal called a graptolite. The skeleton has been flattened during the process of fossilisation. When the animal was alive, each 'saw tooth' was the end of a microscopic tube in which a small animal lived. Graptolites lived in the sea, floating near the surface. They fed on microscopic particles which they were able to filter out of the water.
ComName_tab: , didymograptus patulus, Animalia Chordata Hemichordata Graptolithina
SciName: Animalia & Chordata & Hemichordata & Graptolithina : : : :
LocalSum: UK, England, Cumbria (NW England), Randale Beck (?)

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil brachiopod (Lamp Shell), Spirifer mucronata, collected from unspecified rocks of Devonian age from Canada. Collected by W.K. Loftus (?).
NarNarrative: Spirifer mucronata was a brachiopod (lamp shell) that was common on muddy seabeds during the Devonian period. It would have been well adapted for life in an environment with relatively low levels of plankton. Spirifer brachiopods like these are known as Swallow Stones in China. This is because the shell appears to have long wings.
ComName_tab: Lamp Shell, spirifer mucronatus, Brachiopod Articulata
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Brachiopoda & Articulata : : : Articulata : Brachiopoda

SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Arthropoda & Trilobita : : : :

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil gastropod (snail), Straparollus sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Middle Devonian age from Eifel, Rhine, Germany. Collected by W.K. Loftus (?).
NarNarrative: Straparollus was a gastropod (sea snail) that lived during the Devonian period. Gastropods have a body that looks a bit like a large slug, and live inside a coiled shell that they carry on their back. The body of the gastropod can be completely withdrawn into the shell. The shell of Straparollus has a flattened, coiled shape unlike other species which are shaped more like an ice-cream cone.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil gastropod (snail), Bellerophon sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Middle Devonian age from Eifel, Rhine, Germany. Collected by W.K. Loftus (?).
NarNarrative: Bellerophon was a gastropod (sea snail) that had a rounded shell. Gastropods have a coiled shell that they live in, and a large flattened foot-like muscle, which they crawl on. This gastropod probably looked a bit like a garden snail, but it lived in the sea.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil gastropod, Platyceras sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Middle Devonian age from Eifel, Rhine, Germany. Collected by W.K. Loftus (?).
NarNarrative: Platyceras was a gastropod (sea snail). The shell of this snail is an unusual shape, it has a very wide aperture (mouth), with a frilled edge. This animal was probably a scavenger, eating the remains of dead animals. Fossils of this snail have sometimes been found on the heads of crinoids, and it is possible that Platyceras was eating tiny animals that lived on the surface of crinoids.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil gastropod (snail), Murchisonia bigranulosa, collected from unspecified rocks of Middle Devonian age from Hand, near Paffrath, Germany. Collected by W.K. Loftus.
NarNarrative: Murchisonia bigranulosa was a gastropod (sea snail) that had a tall, pointed shell. It probably spent its life burrowing for food in the seabed. Gastropods move around by crawling on a muscular foot. They can pull their body right inside their shell, and seal off the entrance with a small, hard cover (called an operculum), once they are inside.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil coral, a Honeycomb coral, Favosites sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Devonian age from Gronau, Germany.
NarNarrative: Favosites was a compound or colonial coral, meaning that it formed a hard structure in which lived many small coral animals. These animals are known as polyps and looked a bit like small sea anemones. In this specimen, each small circular depression marks the place where a polyp lived. Favosites lived during the late Ordovician to the Devonian, but is now extinct.
ComName_tab: Honeycomb Coral, favosites sp., Animalia Invertebrata  Anthozoa
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata &  Anthozoa : : : : Coelenterata

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil coral, Alveolites spongites, collected from unspecified rocks of Early Devonian age from Steinbrech, Germany.
NarNarrative: Alveolites was a colonial coral (meaning that it lived with lots of other corals in a colony), which had a calcareous (calcium carbonate) skeleton. Each polyp, which looked like a small sea anemone, lived inside a tube known as a corallite. The corallites of Alveolites had an oval or kidney shaped cross-section.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata &  Anthozoa : : : : Coelenterata

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil coral, Lithostrotion vorticale Parkinson, collected from unspecified rocks of Early Devonian, Lochkovian - Emsian age from Lusheide (?), Bensburg (?), Germany.
NarNarrative: The specimen shows part of the colonial coral Lithostrotion. A living coral polyp, similar to a sea anemone, occupied a cup-shaped hollow at the top of each six-sided corallite. The polyp fed on tiny food particles that it caught in the ring of tentacles around its mouth. Like most corals, Lithostrotion lived attached to the floor of warm, clear, shallow seas near the equator and is often found in reefs.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata &  Anthozoa : : : : Coelenterata

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil coral, Cystiphylloides sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Devonian age from ?, Devon (SW England).
NarNarrative: Cystiphylloides was a solitary coral, which means that a single coral animal (also known as a polyp) lived inside a horn-shaped corallum. This is the name that is given to the hard calcite 'skeleton' in which polyps live. This coral had absent or very short septa, of which there are usually six, or multiples of six inside the corallite, the tube that the polyp lives in. Instead, this coral had blister shaped dissepiments, which are formed by the polyp as it grows, to cut off the lower part of the corallite.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata &  Anthozoa : : : : Coelenterata

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil nautiloid, Orthoceras sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Devonian age from Petit Tor, Torquay, Devon (SW England). Collected by William Pengelly.
NarNarrative: Orthoceras is an extinct ancestor of the modern Nautilus. Unlike the coiled Nautilus, it had a long tapering cone-shaped shell, which was usually straight, but sometimes slightly curved. The largest of these measure over 4 metres long. Like the ammonites, it had tentacles, and possibly moved around by using a jet propulsion system, squirting water from its shell. They were among the largest predators of their time.
ComName_tab: , orthoceras sp., Animalia Invertebrata Mollusca Cephalopoda Nautiloidea
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Nautiloidea : : : :
LocalSum: UK, England, Devon (SW England), Torquay, Petit Tor

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil coral, Thamnopora cervicornis, collected from unspecified rocks of Middle Devonian age from Petit Tor, Torquay, Devon (SW England).
NarNarrative: Thamnopora was a colonial coral, which means that many coral animals (polyps), lived together in a group. This coral had a branched shape, and probably looked like the modern stag's horn coral. Each polyp, which looked a bit like a tiny sea anemone, lived inside a small tube made from the mineral calcite.
ComName_tab: , thamnopora cervicornis (de blainville), Animalia Invertebrata  Anthozoa
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata &  Anthozoa : : : : Coelenterata
LocalSum: UK, England, Devon (SW England), Torquay, Petit Tor

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil coral, Stromatopora concentrica, collected from unspecified rocks of Middle Devonian age from Petit Tor, Torquay, Devon (SW England). Collected by William Pengelly.
NarNarrative: Stomatoporoids, of which Stromatopora concentrica is an example, were common during the Devonian period. They were once thought to be related to corals, but are now recognised as being calcareous (made of calcium carbonate) sponges. Calcareous sponges similar to fossil stromatoporoids, are found in modern oceans today. However, true stromatoporoids are now extinct. They were usually mound-shaped or sheet-like, and were commonly found in reefs (an underwater ridge teeming with life, close to the coast).
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata &  Anthozoa : : : : Coelenterata
LocalSum: UK, England, Devon (SW England), Torquay, Petit Tor

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil coral, Frachastrea goldfussi, collected from unspecified rocks of Middle Devonian age from Ramsley Quarry, Ogwen, Devon (SW England). Collected by William Pengelly.
NarNarrative: Frechastraea goldfussi was a colonial coral, which means that many tiny coral animals, also known as polyps, which looked a bit like sea anemones, lived together in a corallum, a structure made of the mineral calcite. Each polyp lived inside a tube like structure, known as a corallite. Corals usually lived in warm, clear shallow water.
ComName_tab: , frechastraea goldfussi (verneuil and haime), Animalia Invertebrata  Anthozoa
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata &  Anthozoa : : : : Coelenterata

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil crustacean, Estheria membranacea, collected from unspecified rocks of Middle Devonian age from Banniskirk, Caithness (Scotland).
ComName_tab: , estheria membranacea, Animalia Invertebrata Arthropoda Crustacea
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Arthropoda & Crustacea : : : :

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil coral, Phillipsastrea devoniensis Edwards and Haime, collected from unspecified rocks of Late Devonian age from ?, Devon (SW England).
NarNarrative: Phillipastrea devoniensis was a colonial coral, meaning that many coral animals or polyps lived together in a framework made from the mineral calcite. Polyps look a bit like tiny sea anemones, and each one lives inside a tube known as a corallite in the colony.
ComName_tab: , phillipsastrea devoniensis (edwards and haime), Animalia Invertebrata  Anthozoa
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata &  Anthozoa : : : : Coelenterata

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve (mussel), Gervillella sublanceolata, collected from the Tardefurcata Zone = Fissicostatus Zone, Lower Greensand Group of Early Cretaceous, Early Aptian - Albian age from Atherfield, Isle of Wight, Hampshire (SE England).
NarNarrative: The smooth, biconvex (two outward curving) shells of this mussel are of equal size. It lived attached to the sea floor or other mussels by a bunch of strong threads known as a byssus. Gervillella lived in a shallow, warm, tropical sea and fed on microscopic food particles that it filtered out of the sea water.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, Hampshire (SE England), Isle of Wight, Atherfield

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil coral, Syringopora sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Devonian (?) age. Collected by N.C. Cookson, 1874.
NarNarrative: Syringopora was a colonial coral, which consisted of many coral animals (polyps) living together. The polyps looked a bit like small sea anemones, each one living in a separate tube (called a corallite) made of the mineral calcite, which were joined together to form a colony. Corals typically live in warm, clear shallow water, forming a reef, similar to the modern Great Barrier Reef off the coast of Australia. This coral is now extinct.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata &  Anthozoa : : : : Coelenterata

ColPhysicalDescription: Meristina obtusa, collected from the Much Wenlock Limestone Formation of Silurian, Wenlock, Homerian age from Dudley, West Midlands (Midland England). Collected by Emma Smith.
NarNarrative: The photograph shows two views of a complete brachiopod (lamp shell). To the left is a view of the front of the shell. On the right is a side view showing more clearly the two halves of the shell joined together. The shell protected the soft parts of the animal from predation. Brachiopods were attached to the seabed by a stalk (called a pedicle). They fed by filtering particles of food from the sea water.
ComName_tab: Lamp Shell, meristina obtusa (j. sowerby), Brachiopod Articulata
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Brachiopoda & Articulata : : : Articulata : Brachiopoda
LocalSum: UK, England, West Midlands (Midland England), Dudley

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil coral, Kodonophyllum truncatum, collected from the Much Wenlock Limestone Formation (?) of Silurian, Wenlock, Homerian age from Dudley, West Midlands (Midland England). Collected by Emma Smith.
NarNarrative: Take an ice-cream cornet and bend it slightly. Next, push the pointed end into the seabed and place a sea anemone in the top. This will then give you some idea of what these fossil corals might have looked like when alive. There were hundreds of different kinds of coral living in the tropical Silurian sea which must have made the seabed very colourful.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata &  Anthozoa : : : : Coelenterata
LocalSum: UK, England, West Midlands (Midland England), Dudley

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil coral, Thamnopora cristata, collected from the Much Wenlock Limestone Formation (?) of Silurian, Wenlock, Homerian age from Dudley, West Midlands (Midland England).
NarNarrative: Silurian corals, like their present day descendants, show many different growth forms. Some grew in large colonies and formed cushion-shaped mounds. Others grew solitary cone-shaped skeletons. Thamnopora is an example of a colonial coral which grew branch-like skeletons. These were small fragile corals and may have lived in the more sheltered parts of the Silurian reef.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata &  Anthozoa : : : : Coelenterata
LocalSum: UK, England, West Midlands (Midland England), Dudley

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil coral, Thecia swinderniana, collected from the Much Wenlock Limestone Formation (?) of Silurian, Wenlock, Homerian age from Dudley, West Midlands (Midland England).
NarNarrative: In life, the surface of this fossil coral would have been covered with hundreds of coral polyps. These must have made the Silurian seabed blaze with patches of vivid colour. When the coral polyps died, their soft remains decayed away. Only the hard calcium carbonate skeleton remained to become fossilised and form part of the limestone rocks that underlie much of the town of Dudley.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata &  Anthozoa : : : : Coelenterata
LocalSum: UK, England, West Midlands (Midland England), Dudley

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil ammonite, Palyptychites sp., collected from the Speeton Clay Formation of Early Cretaceous, Late Ryazanian - Albian age from North Yorkshire (NE England).
NarNarrative: Ammonites are extinct sea creatures that were similar to octopus and squid, but lived in a coiled shell that provided buoyancy and protection. They were free swimming predators that fed on fish and shrimps. Some also fed on animals that lived on the sea floor. They swam by jet propulsion, forcing water out of their body which pushed them in the opposite direction through the water. The original shell of this ammonite has been well preserved in soft clay.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Ammonoidea : : : Cephalopoda : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Bivalve collected by C. Hickman. Collected from
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil crustacean (barnacle), Balanus concavus, collected from the Red Crag (?) of Quaternary (?), Early (?) Pleistocene age.
NarNarrative: Barnacles are highly specialised crustaceans that have a carapace (skeleton) composed of six hard plates. The plates form a round body chamber known as a capitulum. In Balanus, opercular valves like the specimen shown are used to close the chamber and completely protect the animal's soft body. Barnacles live in high-energy intertidal zones (the area between high and low tide) cemented to rocky seabeds and shells where they feed on tiny plant and animal particles that they filter out of the sea water.
ComName_tab: Barnacle, balanus concavus (bronn), Animalia Invertebrata Arthropoda Crustacea
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Arthropoda & Crustacea : : : :

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil trilobite, Megalaspidella murchisoni, collected from unspecified rocks of Early Ordovician, Arenig age.
NarNarrative: Trilobites possessed a shell composed of a head, a body (thorax) and tail (pygidium). They grew by repeatedly shedding their shells (moulting) and growing a new larger one. The discarded (moulted) shells usually quickly fell to pieces and are the most commonly found trilobite fossils. This rock contains a lot of trilobite tails (pygidia) probably from moulted shells together with the shells from other animals living in the sea.
ComName_tab: , megalaspidella murchisoni (?) (murchison), Animalia Invertebrata Arthropoda Trilobita

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil dropping (coprolite), unidentified, collected from the Oil Shale Formation, Strathclyde Group of Early Carboniferous, Dinantian, Visean, Asbian age from New Breem, Edinburgh (nr.), Scotland. Collected by Susan Turner.
NarNarrative: Coprolites are body waste droppings left by fish and other vertebrates. In low energy (calm water) environments they often retain their original shape. The chemicals released from the coprolite helped form the fine-grained clay ironstone nodule (rocky growth) that has preserved it. The content of coprolites may provide clues about the animals' diet such as bone and mollusc shell fragments. Some coprolites, like this specimen, have an internal structure of concentric cones that are often found in living shark droppings.
LocalSum: UK, Scotland, Lothian (Scotland), Edinburgh (nr.), New Breem

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil brachiopod (Lamp Shell), Pterospirifer alatus, collected from the Ford Formation (reef facies) of Late Permian, Zechstein (Durham Province), EZ1 age from Humbledon Hill, Sunderland, Tyne and Wear (NE England). Collected by James Walter Kirkby.

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Parallelodon striatus, collected from the Ford Formation (reef facies) of Late Permian, Zechstein (Durham Province), EZ1 age from Tunstall Hill, Sunderlane, Tyne and Wear (NE England). Collected by James Walter Kirkby.
NarNarrative: Parallelodon striatus was a bivalve (two shells or valves) that lived on a reef in the warm, salty Zechstein sea 250 million years ago. This sea streched from what is now north east England to Germany and Poland. This bivalve probably lived under pebbles and boulders, and in crevices. It attached itself to rocks with a byssus, strong threads that are formed from a sticky liquid that is poured out of the shell on to a rock.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Stenoscisma humbletonensis, collected from the Ford Formation (reef facies) of Late Permian, Zechstein (Durham Province), EZ1 age from Humbledon Hill, Sunderland, Tyne and Wear (NE England).
NarNarrative: Stenoscismia humbletonensis was a brachiopod (lamp shell) that that lived on a reef in the Zechstein Sea 250 million years ago. This sea streched from what is now north east England to Germany and Poland. It would have lived on the surface of the reef, attaching itself with its pedicle, a long, fibrous muscle that come out of the top of one of the shells through a tiny hole. It would have eaten tiny particles of food that drifted into its slightly open shell.

SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Brachiopoda : : : :

NarNarrative: Stenoscisma lived on a reef, an under sea ridge teeming with life. This brachiopod

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bryozoan (sea mat or moss animal), Fenestella retiformis, collected from the Raisby Formation of Late Permian, Zechstein (Durham Province), EZ1 age from East Thickley, Shildon, Co Durham (NE England).
NarNarrative: The white net-like markings on this piece of rock are the fossilised remains of Fenestella retiformis, a bryozoan (sea mat or moss animal). Bryozoans are sea animals that in some ways are a bit like corals. The white net-like structure formed a framework that housed hundreds of tiny animals, that looked a bit like small sea anemones. The reef that existed in the Sunderland area 250 million years ago included many bryozoans. These were the main reef building animals. Today the main reef builders are corals.
ComName_tab: Sea Mat (or Moss Animal), fenestella retiformis, Animalia Invertebrata Bryozoa
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Bryozoa : : : :
LocalSum: UK, England, Co. Durham (NE England), West Shildon, East Thickley

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bryozoan (sea mat or moss animal), Fenestella retiformis, collected from the Ford Formation (reef facies) of Late Permian, Zechstein (Durham Province), EZ1 age from Humbledon Hill, Sunderland, Tyne and Wear (NE England). Collected by James Walter Kirkby.
NarNarrative: Fenestella retiformis was a bryozoan (sea mat or moss animal) that was common in the Zechstein Sea (a warm, very salty sea) in the Sunderland area 250 million years ago. These fossils are particularly beautiful and delicate and look like white nets on the surface of the rock. They are very common in the rocks of Tunstall Hills in Sunderland which once formed part of a huge tropical barrier reef.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Bryozoa : : : :
LocalSum: UK, England, Tyne and Wear (NE England), Sunderland, Humbledon Hill

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Myalina mytilliformis, collected from unspecified rocks of Permian age from Bridgeport, Illinois, USA. Collected by Prof. McChesney.
NarNarrative: Myalina mytilliformis was a bivalve (meaning two valves or shells) that looked a bit like modern mussels that are found at the seaside. Like modern mussels, Myalina probably attached itself to the sea floor or, for example, driftwood, by byssal threads, which were secreted by glands in the foot, a muscle that some shellfish, especially snails, use to move around.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca
LocalSum: North America, USA, Illinois, Lawrence, Bridgeport

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bryozoan (sea mat or moss animal), Synocladia virgulacea, collected from the Ford Formation (reef facies) of Late Permian, Zechstein (Durham Province), EZ1 age from Co Durham (NE England).
NarNarrative: Synocladia virgulacea was a bryozoan (sea mat or moss animal) that made its home on a reef in the Zechstein Sea 250 million years ago. This sea streched from what is now north east England to Germany and Poland. Bryozoans are animals that live in colonies. When they were alive, the tiny bryozoan animals, that looked a bit like small sea anemones, lived in the fan-shaped structure that has been fossilised.
ComName_tab: Sea Mat (or Moss Animal), synocladia virgulacea (phillips), Animalia Invertebrata Bryozoa
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Bryozoa : : : :

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bryozoan (sea mat or moss animal), Synocladia virgulacea, collected from the Ford Formation (reef facies) of Late Permian, Zechstein (Durham Province), EZ1 age from Co Durham (NE England).
NarNarrative: Synocladia virgulacea was a bryozoan (moss animal) that lived in the warm, salty Zechstein Sea 250 million years ago. This bryozoan built a funnel shaped framework, in which many tiny animals that looked a bit like small sea anemones lived. Bryozoans were important inhabitants of the reef that formed a ridge that can still be traced in the Sunderland area, for example, at Tunstall Hill.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Bryozoa : : : :

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil crustacean (barnacle), Balanus concavus, collected from the Coralline Crag or Red Crag of Tertiary (or Quaternary), Pliocene (or Pleistocene) age from East Anglia (SE England). Collected by William K. Loftus.
NarNarrative: Barnacles are specialised crustaceans that have a carapace (skeleton) composed of six hard plates. The plates are fused together to form a protective chamber for the barnacles soft body. Balanus lives in high-energy intertidal zones (the area between high and low tide) cemented to rocky seabeds and shells where it feeds on food particles that it filters out of the water. The coastal habitat of living barnacles has led to fossil ones being used to identify coastlines in the geological past.
GeoAge: Quaternary & Pleistocene or Tertiary & Pliocene / 0.01 - 5.3 my

NarNarrative: These small brachiopods from German rocks of Permian age are found in rocks of the same age (250 million years) in the Sunderland area. The Zechstein Sea that then covered part of the Sunderland area, reached as far East as Northern Germany, which is why similar fossils are found there. This brachiopod lived on the sea floor, anchoring itself with a pedicle, a long thin muscle, which came out through a hole in one of the shells.

ColPhysicalDescription: Cleiothyridina pectinifera, collected from the Ford Formation (reef facies) of Late Permian, Zechstein (Durham Province), EZ1 age from Humbledon Hill, Sunderland, Tyne and Wear (NE England). Collected by Richard Howse (?).
NarNarrative: Cleorithyridina pectinifera was a brachiopod (lamp shell) that lived on a reef (a community teeming with life) in a warm sea in the Sunderland area 250 million years ago. This sea streched from what is now north east England to Germany and Poland. It often lived in groups known as nests, and waited for particles of food to drift into its slightly open shell. Occasionally some of these fossils show the coiled spiralia, which supports the lophophore, a food-collecting organ inside the shell. It is amazing that even these internal organs have been fossilised.

NarNarrative: Thamniscus dubius was a bryozoan (moss animal or sea mat) that lived on a reef in the warm Zechstein Sea 250 million years ago. This sea streched from what is now north east England to Germany and Poland. Bryozoans were reef-building animals (reefs like this one often form ridges), similar to corals. This particular bryozoan formed branching, plant-like structures, in which the tiny zooids (bryozoan animals) that looked a bit like small sea anemones, lived.

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil nautiloid, Peripetoceras freieslebeni, collected from the Ford Formation (reef facies) of Late Permian, Zechstein (Durham Province), EZ1 age from Tunstall Hill, Sunderland, Tyne and Wear (NE England). Collected by James Walter Kirkby.
NarNarrative: Peripetoceras freieslebeni was a nautiloid, an animal similar to the modern Nautilus that lives in the Pacific Ocean. It probably ate small sea creatures that lived on the reef that flourished in the warm water of the Zechstein Sea, 250 million years ago. The actual animal lived at the open end of the shell and had a set of tentacles much like a modern squid. The shell was filled with gas which allowed it to float at various depths in the water. It moved by squirting a jet of water through an organ called a siphuncle. This is a form of jet propulsion.

SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Nautiloidea : : : :

NarNarrative: This fossil shows us what the inside of this shellfish looked like. The outside of the shell has been dissolved away. During the seventeenth century, these strangely shaped fossils became known as 'Osses 'Eds, because it was thought that they looked a bit like horses heads. In actual fact the shapes on the fossil are showing us where muscles and other internal organs were attached to the inside of the shell.

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Pleuromya uniformis, collected from unspecified rocks of Middle to Late Jurassic age.
NarNarrative: Pholadomya fidicula is a bivalve (meaning two shells or valves) that spent its adult life buried under the seabed. It used a siphon (a tube that came out from between its shells) to feed on microscopic (smaller than the eye can see) animals and plants in the sea. This seashell has many fine ridges that curve around the shell parallel to its edge. If you look closely, you can see some wavy lines that cut across the ridges, especially near the apex (top) of the shell. These may help to strengthen the shell.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Cardinia listeri J. Sowerby, collected from the Lower Lias of Early Jurassic age from Redcar, North Yorkshire (NE England). Collected by M.B. Gardener.
NarNarrative: Cardinia listeri was a bivalve (two valves or shells). It lived in a burrow, probably in a muddy seabed, and fed on tiny particles of food suspended in the water. This bivalve has a triangular shell, but the shells of most bivalves are more rounded than this.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, North Yorkshire (NE England), Redcar

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil gastropod (snail), Bathrotomaria reticulata J. Sowerby, collected from unspecified rocks of Late Jurassic, Oxfordian - Kimmeridgian age.
NarNarrative: These fossilised gastropods (sea snails) are similar to the modern sea snails that are found today living mainly in warm seas. These are often called 'top' shells because they look like a spinning top. These animals probably lived in shallow water close to the seashore. They probably ate protozoa (tiny single-celled organisms that lived in the sea), and the remains of other creatures that had died.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve (oyster), Liostrea delta, collected from unspecified rocks of Late Jurassic, Callovian age.
NarNarrative: This fossil of an oyster shell looks very similar to modern oyster shells. Modern oysters usually have a rough looking, slightly curved shell, and a smaller flatter shell. Oysters usually spend their adult lives attached to a solid object such as a rock on the seabed or on top of another shell. They actually glue themselves on using a kind of cement made from the same material as the shell.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Bivalve
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil coral, Isastrea sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Middle to Late Jurassic age.
NarNarrative: Isastrea is a fossil coral from a Jurassic coral reef. Each of the small five or six-sided holes that you can see on the surface of this fossil used to contain a tiny coral animal (called a polyp), that looked a little bit like a very small sea anemone. The hard, fossilised remains that you can see here was the 'skeleton' of the coral, which provided a home for the tiny coral animals.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata &  Anthozoa : : : : Coelenterata

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Gresslya sp., collected from the Oxford Clay of Late Jurassic, Oxfordian age from Weymouth Harbour, Weymouth, Dorset (SW England).
NarNarrative: Gresslya was a bivalve (meaning two shells or valves), that spent its life living deeply buried in soft mud or sand. It had two long siphons that protruded between its shells, which it stretched up to the top of its burrow. One of the siphons was used to trap particles of food from the sea water, the other siphon was used to pass out waste products.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, Dorset (SW England), Weymouth, Weymouth Harbour

SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Ammonoidea : : : Cephalopoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, North Yorkshire (NE England), Whitby

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil ammonite, Amaltheus stokesi, collected from the Middle Lias rocks of Early Jurassic age from North Yorkshire (NE England).
NarNarrative: An ammonite from the Early Jurassic rocks of the Yorkshire coast. This ammonite has a very 'flat' shell, when compared with other ammonites of Jurassic age, such as Cadoceras and Macrocephalites. The ribs on the shell of this ammonite are distinctly curved. If you look closely, you will see that there are extra small ribs along the keel. Ammonites moved by squirting a jet of water through an organ called the siphuncle. Ammonites with sharp keels (like the bottom of a boat) were probably able to move through the water more quickly than rounder shaped ammonites.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Ammonoidea : : : Cephalopoda : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil ammonite, Lytoceras fimbriatum, collected from the Margaritatus Zone, Middle Lias of Early Jurassic, Late Pliensbachian age from Lyme Regis, Dorset (SW England).
NarNarrative: Lytoceras fimbricatum was an ammonite that lived in the Jurassic seas. It was alive at the same time as the dinosaurs, and was preyed upon (eaten) by large marine reptiles like pliosaurs that also lived in the sea. Ammonites are now extinct (they died out at the same time as the dinosaurs, 65 million years ago), and were similar to the modern pearly nautilus that lives in the warm waters of the Pacific Ocean.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Ammonoidea : : : Cephalopoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, Dorset (SW England), Lyme Regis

NarNarrative: This fossil crab looks like a living shore crab. It has been preserved in the soft mud in which it lived. The fossil crab lived on a muddy sea floor probably in shallow water such as an esuary or a mud flat. The crab extracted small food particles out of the mud that it ate.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Arthropoda & Crustacea : : : :
