ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Glycymeris brevirostris, collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary (?), Early (?) Eocene age.
NarNarrative: This shellfish lived in a vertical position in a shallow burrow on a sandy sea bed and fed on tiny food particles that it filtered out of the sea water. This group of fossils contains many single shells, which suggests that they were washed together by sea currents after they died. This is because each shellfish had two shells joined together when they were alive which broke apart when they died. Glycymeris lived near the coast and were often washed out of their burrows during storms.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve (oyster), Ostrea sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary (?) age.
NarNarrative: Fossil oysters had thick shells that protected their soft bodies in high-energy (rough water) coastal environments. The ribs are present only on the concave shell that was fixed to the sea floor; the other shell was smaller, flat and opened like a lid. They formed large colonies along coasts and are often used to identify ancient shorelines. They fed on tiny food particles that they filtered out of the water. The holes in the shell were bored by worms.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Pecten sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary (?) age.
NarNarrative: The slightly convex thin scallop shell has prominent wings and is covered with radiating ribs that strengthen it. Pecten lived freely on the seabed and fed on tiny food particles that it filtered out of the water. It could also swim by 'clapping' its two shells together but usually only did so to escape from predators. The hole in the shell was made by a predatory gastropod so that it could feed on scallop's soft body.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil gastropod, Athleta spinosus, collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary, Eocene age from Paris Basin, France.
NarNarrative: The thick sea snail shell is covered with spiral ridges and vertical ribs. Athleta lived in warm subtropical shallow coastal waters in a community dominated by gastropods and bivalves. It was a predator and a scavenger that fed on live molluscs, dead animals and plants on the sea floor. The snail shell was one of the first British fossils to be given a scientific name using the new Linnean classification system by Daniel Solander in 1766.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil gastropod, Globularia sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary, Eocene age from Paris Basin, France.
NarNarrative: The globe shaped shell gives this sea snail its classified name. The soft body of the snail filled the last coil of the shell with the round opening. Globularia was a predator that fed on bivalves that lived buried in the surface of the sea floor. It was part of a rich and varied bivalve-gastropod fauna shallow that lived in a warm shallow subtropical sea.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil gastropod (snail), Turritella sulcifera, collected from the Bracklesham Group of Tertiary, Early - Middle Eocene, Late Ypresian - Lutetian age from Bracklesham, Sussex (SE England).
NarNarrative: This sea snail is named from its slender cone-shaped or 'turreted' shell. The shell lay flat or inclined gently downwards so that the snails body was level with the sea floor where its food supply was most abundant. It fed on micro-organisms and other tiny food particles that it filtered out of the sea water. It was part of a rich and varied gastropod-bivalve fauna found on the floor of a warm shallow subtropical sea.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil gastropod (snail), Neritina conoidea, collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary, Eocene age from Paris Basin, France.
NarNarrative: The round body chamber of this sea snail encloses the early coils of its shell. The slit-like opening in the shell had a siphon (tube) at each end, which the snail used to pump water into and away from its body. The snail fed on tiny food particles that it filtered out of the water. Neritina lived in warm water on the floor of a large lake basin that was flooded by the sea from time to time.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil gastropod (snail), Cerithium serratum, collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary, Eocene age from Paris Basin, France.
NarNarrative: This sea snail has a slender cone-shaped shell with many angular coils covered in spiny nodes. Cerithium lived on the muddy floor of a large lake basin that was flooded by the sea from time to time as sea levels varied. It was part of the rich gastropod-bivalve fauna that lived in the warm subtropical waters. The snail probably lived with its shell partially buried and fed on tiny food particles that it filtered out of the water.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Glycymeris glycymeris, collected from the Red Crag of Quaternary, Early Pleistocene age from Walton-on-the-Naze, Essex (SE England). Collected by William K. Loftus.
NarNarrative: The outside of this round single bivalve shell has fine radiating ribs (ridges) that are cut by the growth lines (lines created as the shell grew larger). The unusual marks on the shell are borings that were made by sea-living worms. Glycymeris lived in a vertical position in a shallow burrow on sandy seabeds. It fed on tiny food particles that it filtered out of sea water. When the animal died the two valves usually separated.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, Essex (SE England), Felixtowe (nr.), Walton on the Naze

ColPhysicalDescription: Polished ammonite cross-section.
Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Glycymeris sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary age.
NarNarrative: This common round bivalve shell has equally sized convex (outward curving) shells with ribs on the outside. Glycimeris lived in a vertical position buried in the surface of a sandy seabed. The two shells have remained locked together which suggests that this specimen was probably buried alive in its burrow. It lived in shallow coastal water including the intertidal zone (the area between high and low tide) and fed on tiny food particles that it filtered out of the sea water.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Artica sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary age.
NarNarrative: This common oval-shaped bivalve seashell has equally sized convex (outward curving) shells with closely spaced growth lines on the outside. It lived in a vertical position buried in a sandy sea floor with the pointed umbones (the pointed ends of the shells) facing to the side. It had leathery siphon tubes that reached up to the seabed surface, which it used to pump water through its body and filter out tiny food particles. Artica lived in shallow water including intertidal areas (the area between high and low tide).
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil gastropod, Planobina euomphalus, collected from the Perforata Zone, Solent Group, Headon Hill Formation, Headon Beds Member of Tertiary, Oligocene age from Headon Hill, Isle of Wight, Hampshire (SE England).
NarNarrative: This snail is unusual because it has a fairly flat shell with a left-handed coil (most snails have a right-handed coil). It usually lived in fresh water and is often used to identify rocks that were deposited in fresh water. This specimen was found in rocks deposited in fresh and brackish (slightly salty) water lagoons, rivers and lakes that formed in flat low-lying land close to the coast when the climate was subtropical.
GeoRock: Solent Group & Headon Hill Formation & Headon Beds Member
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, Hampshire (SE England), Isle of Wight, Headon Hill

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Venus casina, collected from the Red Crag of Quaternary, Early Pleistocene age from Suffolk (SE England).
NarNarrative: The outside of this common bivalve is covered with even-spaced lamellae (ridges). Mya lived in a vertical position in a burrow about 5 centimetres deep on sandy seabeds in coastal areas including the intertidal zone (the area between high and low tide). There is a gap between the two shells where a leathery siphon (tube) reached up to the seabed so that it could suck in water that contained oxygen and food. When the bivalve died its two shells were usually held together by the burrow.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Glycymeris glycymeris, collected from the Coralline Crag of Tertiary, Pliocene age from Suffolk (SE England).
NarNarrative: This round bivalve has equally sized convex (outward curving) shell. It lived in a vertical position buried in the surface of the sea floor with the pointed ends (umbones) facing to the side. Siphons (tubes) ran from inside the shell to the sea floor and were used to pump water through its body. Glycymeris fed on tiny food particles that it filtered out of the water.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil crustacean (Barnacle) Balanus sp., encrusting a bivalve, Cyrena sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary, Eocene or Oligocene age from Bembridge, Isle of Wight, Hampshire (SE England). Barnacles encrusting bivalve.
NarNarrative: Barnacles are a special type of crustacean (the same group of animals as crabs and lobsters). They are able to live in areas where the sea waves beat against the rocks. They live cemented (stuck) to rocks or the shells of bivalves and other animals on the sea floor. Cyrena is a bivalve shellfish that lived in a burrow. After the bivalve died its two shells separated. The barnacles then grew on the empty shell. Both animals fed on tiny food particles that they filtered out of the sea water.
ComName_tab: Barnacle, balanus sp., Animalia Invertebrata Arthropoda Crustacea
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Arthropoda & Crustacea : : : :
LocalSum: UK, England, Hampshire (SE England), Isle of Wight, Bembridge

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil ammonite, Hamites sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Early (?) Cretaceous age.
NarNarrative: This unusual ammonite shell has two straight sections joined by a U-bend and is covered with widely spaced simple ribs. The animal itself (which looked like a small octopus) lived in the wider end of the shell. The reason for this unusual shape is unclear but it may be an adaptation for living on the sea floor (ammonites are usually free-swimming). Hamites lived all over the world in the Cretaceous period before it became extinct towards the end of the period, along with animal like the dinosaurs.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Ammonoidea : : : Cephalopoda : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve (oyster), Rastellum carinatum, collected from the Mantelli Zone, Cambridge Greensand of Late Cretaceous, Early Cenomanian age from Cambridgeshire (SE England).
NarNarrative: This oyster shell has wide, angled ribs that have led to it being called the 'denture clam'. The zig-zag join between the two shells stopped coarse dirt and debris entering the shell and damaging its soft body. Like modern oysters it lived in shallow coastal waters including the intertidal zone (the area between high and low tide) and fed on food particles that it filtered out of the sea water. When this oyster died and its two shells separated before one was preserved in the beach deposit where it was found.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Echinoid
SciName: Conulus : : : Echinoidea : Echinodermata

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil gastropod (snail), a Portland Screw, Aptyxiella portlandica, collected from the Portland Stone of Late Jurassic, Tithonian age from Dorset (SW England).
NarNarrative: This specimen is a limestone cast of the inside of a sea snail shell. The original shell formed the mould and was later dissolved away by weakly acidic water. The cast shows that the inside of the shell was very smooth. The slender shape, appearance and the locality where it was found have led the fossil being commonly known as a Portland Screw. The gastropod lived in shallow coastal waters of a warm subtropical sea.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil brachiopod, Terebratula sp., collected rom the Chalk Formation of Late Cretaceous age.
NarNarrative: The shell of this fossil brachiopod is very smooth, the only markings on it are fine growth lines. When it was alive it was attached to the sea floor by a pedicle (fleshy stalk) which grew through the hole in the larger of the two shells. Terebratula lived in quiet, shallow, offshore waters where it often formed small colonies. It fed on tiny food particles that it filtered out of the sea water.
ComName_tab: Lamp Shell, terebratula sp., Animalia Invertebrata Brachiopoda
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Brachiopoda : : : :

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil crustacean (crab), Titanocarcinus sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary, Oligocene age from Limbourge, Belgium. Collected by David M. Lumsden.
NarNarrative: Crabs are well known crustaceans that are found in coastal areas. They have a tough exoskeleton (a hard outer shell) made out of chitin, a material similar to finger nails. They are predators and feed mainly on shellfish that they break open with their claws. The specimen is a well-preserved body carapace (shell) covered with small protective spikes. There are no legs or claws attached to the carapace suggesting that it may be one that was shed when the crab moulted (replaced it shell) during growth.
ComName_tab: Crab, titanocarcinus sp., Animalia Invertebrata Arthropoda Crustacea
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Arthropoda & Crustacea : : : :

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil insect, unidentified, collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary, Oligocene, Rupelian (= Stampian) age from Apt, Stampian Provence, France. Collected by David M. Lumsden.
NarNarrative: These two different flies have been preserved as fossils in freshwater lake sediments. Specimen a shows a dipteron type fly (like a house fly) that has a large segmented (divided) abdomen (lower part of the body), a smaller thorax (upper part of the body) with three of its six legs attached, head and wings. Specimen b looks like a crane fly or mosquito with its long thin body, rounded thorax, fine elongate wings and two small antennae. The flies were probably part of a large insect population in the sub-tropical forests that surrounded the lake.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Arthropoda & Insecta : : : :

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil brachiopod, Liothyrella landonensis, collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary, Oligocene age from Canterbury, New Zealand. Collected by David M. Lumsden.
NarNarrative: This smooth, round brachiopod shell with growth lines, is a Southern Hemisphere species. In life it was attached to the sea floor by a pedicle (fleshy stalk) that grew from the round hole in the pointed tip of the shell. Like most brachiopods in probably lived in an open sea where the salinity (salt content) was normal. It fed on tiny food particles that it filtered out of the sea water.
ComName_tab: Lamp Shell, liothyrella landonensis, Brachiopod Articulata
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Brachiopoda & Articulata : : : Articulata : Brachiopoda

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil echinoid (sea urchin), Echinus sp., collected from the Coralline Crag or Red Crag of Tertiary, Pliocene (or Pleistocene ?) age from Suffolk (SE England).
NarNarrative: In life, the test (skeleton) of this fossil sea urchin was covered with spines. The spines helped the sea urchin move and provided protection from predators. The hole in the base of the test contained a toothed feeding apparatus that surrounded the mouth. It fed on living and dead animals that it found on the sea floor. Echinus has survived to the present day and is found in coastal waters around the British Isles.
GeoAge: Tertiary & Pliocene or Quaternary & Pleistocene (?) / 0 - 5.3 my (c)
SciName: Echinoidea : : : : Echinodermata

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of fossil corals, Turbinolia sp., and Caryophyllia (?) sp. collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary, Pliocene age from Parma, Italy.
NarNarrative: These horn-shaped skeletons of the fossil corals Turbinolia and Caryophyllia were attached to the sea floor at the pointed end. The living coral polyp (animal) lived in the cup-shaped hollow at the wide end of the horn. The polyp looked like a sea anemone with a mouth in the centre surrounded by a ring of tentacles that it used to collect tiny animals for food. Like most corals it probably lived in warm shallow tropical seas.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata &  Anthozoa : : : : Coelenterata

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil brachiopod (Lamp Shell), Terebratula sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary age.
NarNarrative: This oval brachiopod (lamp shell) has a smooth shell with fine regularly spaced growth lines. It lived in a warm, shallow sea where it was attached to the sea floor by a pedicle (fleshy stalk) that grew through the round hole in the pointed tip of the shell. It fed on microscopic animals and tiny food particles that it filtered out of the water.
ComName_tab: Lamp Shell, terebratula sp., Animalia Invertebrata Brachiopoda
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Brachiopoda : : : :

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil gastropod, Pyrula rustica, collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary age from Bordeaux, France. Collected by Charlton.
NarNarrative: This shell has an unusually long tube that ran from the round chamber that protected the sea snail's soft body. The tube contained the snail's inhalant siphon that piped water and nutrients to the gills and prevented it being mixed up with waste water pumped out of the body. Pyrula lived in a warm, shallow sea and fed on microscopic food particles that it filtered out of the water.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Mya sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary, Miocene age from Bordeaux, France. Collected by Charlton.
NarNarrative: This bivalve has similar sized convex (outward curving) shells with concentric lamellae (ridges) and faint growth lines. Mya lived at the bottom of a deep burrow. It had a leathery tube that ran through a gap between the shells up to the seabed. It used this tube to maintain a supply of water for oxygen and food. It fed on microscopic food particles that it filtered out of the water. When the animal died its two shells were usually held together by the burrow.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia & Heterodonta & Myoida : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil gastropod, Ficula reticulata, collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary, Miocene age from Bordeaux, France. Collected by Charlton.
NarNarrative: The shape of this sea snail has lead to it commonly being called a fig shell because it looks like the fruit. The coiled shell narrows into a short tube that provided protection for the siphon tube which took water into the snails' body. The snail lived on the muddy floor of a warm, subtropical sea and was part of a rich and varied bivalve and gastropod community.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Cardita sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary, Miocene age from Bordeaux, France. Collected by Charlton.
NarNarrative: This bivalve's shell has a pattern of wide ridges and narrow grooves. Cardita lived in shallow coastal areas where it burrowed into the surface of sandy seabeds and fed on tiny food particles that it filtered out of the water. The bivalve pushed a short leathery tube up to the seabed when its shell was opened. The tube contained two siphons, one supplied the snail with water, oxygen and food and the other removed waste out of the snail.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Crab
ComName_tab: Crab, tumidocarcinus giganteus, Animalia Invertebrata Arthropoda Crustacea
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Arthropoda & Crustacea : : : :

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve (ship worm), Teredina personata, collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary age from Bernon, Epernay (nr.), France. Collected by William K. Loftus (?).
NarNarrative: This bivalve has adapted to burrowing into wood. Living relatives are often called shipworms even though they are not true worms. The shells are much reduced in size and the body is barely recognisable as a bivalve. The shells are used as tools to drill circular burrows that were then lined with the mineral calcite. The cellulose in the wood is digested as food although they fed mainly on tiny food particles that they filtered out of the water.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve (mussel), Mytilus sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary age.
NarNarrative: This is typical mussel shell and has two equally sized shells. Like its modern counterpart, it would have lived in coastal areas, either on a rocky shore or in a river estuary. It survives in these high-energy environments by anchoring itself to rocks or other shells using a tough bunch of threads known as a byssus. The shells open when they are covered by water. Mytilus fed on food particles that it filtered out of the water.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil gastropod, Scaphella lamberti, collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary, Pliocene age from Lours (?), France.
NarNarrative: This smooth spindle-shaped sea snail lived in a warm shallow sea with a soft clay floor. It fed on tiny food particles that it filtered out of the water. A short and pointed groove (canal) is present at the base of the opening in the snail shell. The canal contained and protected a soft tube that carried fresh water and nutrients to the gills and prevented it being mixed up with waste water pumped out of the body.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve (mussel), Potomida littoralis, collected from the Lower Barnwell Gravel of Quaternary, Holocene, Flandrian age from Barnwell, Cambridge, Cambridgeshire (SE England). Collected by A.G. Dew-Smith.
NarNarrative: This living bivalve is better known by its earlier name of Unio littoralis. The equally sized shells are covered in growth lines. It lived on or partly buried in the surface of freshwater sediments and fed on tiny food particles that it filtered out of the water. Potomida has an unusual life cycle; its larvae are parasitic and live on fish before they emerge as young animals, which helps distribute the mussel.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, Cambridgeshire (SE England), Cambridge, Barnwell

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Mya truncata, collected from the Clyde Beds of Quaternary, Pleistocene, Late Devensian, Windermere Interstadial age from Scotland. Collected by H. Crosskey.
NarNarrative: This bivalve shellfish has two similar shaped shells covered with faint growth lines. There is a large gap between the two shells which gives the bivalve its common name of 'blunt gaper'. Mya lived at the bottom of a deep burrow on mixed sand and mud seabeds. It had a leathery siphon (tube) that extended through the gap up to the seabed. The siphon supplied water with oxygen and tiny food particles for the animal to live.
GeoAge: Quaternary & Pleistocene & Devensian (Late) & Windermere Interstadial / 10,200 - 13,780 years
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil gastropod (limpet), Patella lamarkii, collected from the Marine Calcareous Beds of Tertiary, Pliocene age from Sicily.
NarNarrative: This gastropod is unusual because its shell is a simple cone. It is well adapted to life in the high energy (rough water) environment of the intertidal zone (the area between high and low tide) where it clings to rocks with the sole of its rounded foot. The shell provides protection from predators and stops the soft bodied animal drying up when the tide is out. When covered with water the limpet moves around and grazes on algae. The species is named after the French naturalist and evolutionist Lamarck.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil gastropod, Cassidaria sp., collected from the Marine Calcareous Beds of Tertiary, Pliocene age from Sicily.
NarNarrative: The shape of this sea snail's thick shell has lead to it being called a 'helmet shell' or 'bonnet'. The outside of the shell has a pattern of spiral cords (rope-like pattern) and nodes. Present day relatives live in coastal areas of shallow, tropical and cool, temperate seas. They are active predators on sandy and rocky shores ands feed mainly on bivalves. Some larger forms are prized for carving cameos.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil crustacean (crab), Trichopeltiaion greggi, collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary, Pliocene age from Canterbury, New Zealand. Collected by David M. Lumsden.
NarNarrative: The claw and part of the abdomen of this crab has been preserved in a calcareous nodule (a limy growth in the rock). Crabs are well known crustaceans that have a tough exoskeleton ) external shell) made out of a material called chitin that is similar to finger nails. The skeleton protects them in the high energy (rough water) shoreline environments. They are predators and feed mainly on bivalves and gastropods that they break open with their claws. Crabs are fairly common fossils in soft Tertiary sedimentary rocks.
ComName_tab: Crab, trichopeltiaion greggi, Animalia Invertebrata Arthropoda Crustacea
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Arthropoda & Crustacea : : : :

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bryozoan (sea mat or moss animal), Theona globosa, collected from the Coralline Crag of Tertiary, Pliocene age from Orford, Suffolk (SE England). Collected by William K. Loftus.
NarNarrative: The skeleton of this bryozoan colony, as its name suggests, is globe shaped. It consists of a lot of calcareous (made of calcium carbonate) tubes that were made by the thousands of microscopic animals called zooids that lived in them. The zooids fed on tiny microscopic plants known as phytoplankton that they trapped in their tentacles. Like most bryozoans this colony lived in shallow water at depths between 20 and 80m where their phytoplankton food was most commonly found.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bryozoan (sea mat or moss animal), Meandropora aurantium, collected from the Coralline Crag (?) of Tertiary, Pliocene (?) age from Aldborough, Suffolk (SE England). On wood label.
NarNarrative: The skeleton of this globe-shaped bryozoan colony is made up of many hexagonal (six-sided) calcareous (made of calcium carbonate) tubes arranged in a honeycomb pattern. The tubes were built by the thousands of microscopic animals called zooids that lived in the colony. The zooids fed on tiny microscopic plants known as phytoplankton that they trapped in their tentacles. Like most bryozoans this colony lived in shallow water at depths between 20 and 80m where their phytoplankton food was most abundant.
ComName_tab: Sea Mat (or Moss Animal), meandropora aurantium, Animalia Invertebrata Bryozoa
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Bryozoa : : : :

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of two fossil bryozoa (sea mat or moss animal), Retepora cellulosa, and Retepora simplex (Johnston), collected from the Coralline Crag of Tertiary, Pliocene age from Aldborough, Suffolk (SE England).
NarNarrative: The skeleton of this bryozoan colony is made up of many hexagonal (six-sided) calcareous (made of calcium carbonate) tubes that are joined together and arranged in folded sheets. The tubes were built by the thousands of microscopic animals called zooids that lived in the colony. The zooids fed on tiny microscopic plants known as phytoplankton that they trapped in their tentacles. Like most bryozoans this colony lived in shallow water at depths between 20 and 80m where their phytoplankton food was most abundant.
ComName_tab: Sea Mat (or Moss Animal), retepora cellulosa (johnston), Animalia Invertebrata Bryozoa
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Bryozoa : : : :

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, unidentified, collected from unspecified rocks of Late Triassic, Rhaetic age from the coast at Penarth, Cardiff, Glamorgan (Wales). Collected by Emma Smith.
NarNarrative: These small bivalves (sea shells) are from rocks of Rhaetic (Late Triassic) age. During much of the Triassic, Northern Europe had a hot, dry climate. Rising sea levels at the end of the Triassic period led to an increase in sea-living animals, including bivalves.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Trigonia juddiana, collected from the Kimmeridge Clay of Late Jurassic, Kimmeridgian age from Market Raisen, Lincolnshire (Midland England). Possibly collected by Richard Howse.
NarNarrative: This bivalve (meaning two valves or shells), has a very thick shell. Today, it can still be found living off the coast of Australia. During the Jurassic period, when the UK was closer to the Equator, the sea was warmer. The temperature of sea water is a strong influence on the kind of animals that live in it. Often, a greater variety of life will be found in warmer seas.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, Lincolnshire (Midland England), Market Rasen

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil crustacean (lobster), Paraglyphea rostra, collected from the Corallian Beds of Late Jurassic, Oxfordian age from Jack Lions Pit, Malton, Yorkshire (NE England). Collected by D.M. Lumsden.
NarNarrative: Only a small part of the lobster has been fossilised. The head, claws, legs and tail are missing. This may be because the lobster broke up after it died, or because parts of the fossil broke off more recently. This fossil lobster would have looked quite similar to modern lobsters.
ComName_tab: , paraglyphea rostra, Animalia Invertebrata Arthropoda Crustacea Malacostraca
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Arthropoda & Crustacea & Malacostraca : : : :
LocalSum: UK, England, North Yorkshire (NE England), Malton, Jack Lions Pit

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Lopha marshi, collected from unspecified rocks of Jurassic age.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil belemnite, Megateuthis paxillosus, collected from the Lower Lias of Early Jurassic age from Blockley, Gloucestershire (SW England). Collected by D.M. Lumsden.
NarNarrative: This fossil is from a belemnite, a squid-like animal that lived in the sea. The remains of belemnites have been found inside the stomachs of ichthyosaurs, large marine (sea-living)reptiles that looked a bit like dolphins. The part of a belemnite that is usually found as a fossil is called the guard, and it looks a bit like a large bullet. This fossil is actually the phragmocone, the section of the shell that held the soft body of the belemnite which lies just in front of the guard.
ComName_tab: , megateuthis paxillosus, Animalia Invertebrata Mollusca Cephalopoda Belemnoidea
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Belemnoidea : : : :

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil blastoid, Pentremites godoni, collected from unspecified rocks of Early Carboniferous, Mississippian age from Wax, Kentucky, USA. Collected by David M. Lumsden. Three calyx.
NarNarrative: Pentremites is one of the best known Blastoids, an extinct group of echinoderms. The bud-shaped calyx (the body) has five-sided symmetry and contained the animals' organs. It was attached to the sea floor by a stalk and had a crown of delicate arms that it used to collect food particles. The mouth is in the centre of the top surrounded by five circular holes known as spiracles one of which contains the anus. Blastoids are most commonly found in shallow water reef communities.
SciName: Blastoidea : : : : Echinodermata
LocalSum: North America, USA, Kentucky, Grayson, Wax

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Unicardium sp., collected from the Cornbrash rocks of Middle to Late Jurassic age from Rushden (?), Northamptonshire (Midland England).
NarNarrative: Unicardium is a bivalve seashell (meaning two shells or valves). Cardium means 'of the heart'. The name was probably given to these shells because, when the two joined shells are viewed from the side, they have a heart-like shape. This fossil is a cast of the inside of the shell. Fossils of the outside of shells are more common. If you look closely, you can see that there are no fine lines or decoration on the surface of this fossil, which you would see if this was showing the outside of the shell. Casts like these form when the inside of the shell fills with mud or sand which eventually hardens. When the actual shell around this dissolves away the intenal cast is left behind. Sometimes you can see details of the surface of the inside of the shell such as areas where the muscles were attached.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Pleuromya costata, collected from the Lias of Early Jurassic age from North Yorkshire (NE England). Collected by Albany Hancock (et.al.).
NarNarrative: Pleuromya costata is a bivalve (meaning two valves or shells), from rocks of early Jurassic age. Pleuromya lived below the sea floor, buried in layers of mud or silt (which is finer than sand). It used a siphon (a tube), that stuck out between its shells, and up into the water above the sea floor, to suck in its food. Modern relatives of this shell fish feed on tiny plants and animals that live in sea water.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil ammonite, Cadoceras sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Jurassic (?) age. Single shell showing suture in places.
NarNarrative: Cadoceras is an ammonite that has a very rounded shape. This shape is quite unusual, as the shells of most ammonites are much flatter. Ammonites lived in the sea, and moved around by using a jet-propulsion system, which means that they squirted water out of their shells, to help them travel in the opposite direction. Ammonites were similar to the modern Nautilus that lives in the warm waters of the Pacific Ocean. They were eaten by large marine reptiles such as the dolphin-like ichthyosaurs, which were alive at the same time as the dinosaurs.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Ammonoidea : : : Cephalopoda : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve (oyster), Gryphaea bilobata, collected from the Kellaways Rock of Late Jurassic, Callovian age.
NarNarrative: Gryphaea bilobata is related to the modern oyster. The two shells of this fossil have very different shapes. The larger shell is curved, and quite thick. The smaller shell is flat. In the early part of its life, this shellfish would have attached itself to the seabed or some other hard surface. Gryphea bilobata would have spent its adult life living unattached on the sea floor, partly buried in the sand or mud.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil ammonite, Harpoceratoides strangwaysi, collected from the Falciferum Zone, Upper Lias rocks of Early Jurassic age. Single shell.
NarNarrative: Haropoceratoides strangwaysi is an ammonite from rocks of early Jurassic age. The suture lines (the joins between the sections that make up the shell) show up as pale grey lines on the surface of this fossil, and are very clear. Suture lines form as the ammonite grows, and sometimes look very 'frilly'.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Ammonoidea : : : Cephalopoda : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Plagiostoma lacoruscula, collected from the Corallian Oolite of Late (?) Jurassic, Oxfordian (?) age from Malton, Yorkshire (NE England).
NarNarrative: Plagiostoma lacoruscula is a bivalve (meaning two valves or shells). Plagiostoma usually lived on the seabed, and used fine thread-like outgrowths (called a byssus), to anchor themselves to either the sea floor, or sometimes another shell. They probably got their food by filtering sea water for small particles.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, North Yorkshire (NE England), Malton

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil ammonite, Promicroceras planicosta, collected from the Obtusum Zone, Lower Lias rocks of Early Jurassic age from Marston Magna, near Yeovil, Somerset (SW England). Monospecific ammonite coquina.
NarNarrative: Fossilised shells piled together like these ammonites are described as a 'death assemblage'. Ammonites swam in the sea, and would only form a group like this after they had died and fallen to the sea bed. Some of these ammonites are partly coated in a shiny pale-coloured material. This has replaced the shells of the ammonites.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Ammonoidea : : : Cephalopoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, Somerset (SW England), Yeovil (nr.), Marston Magna

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil ammonite, cf Liparoceras sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Jurassic (?) age. except that specimen only has single tubucles.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Ammonoidea : : : Cephalopoda : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: 120 x 70 x 30 mm bone with some host rock attached.
Fragments up to 40mm long some of which are phosphatised.
Specimen of a fossil crustacean (crab), Macropthalmus latreillei, collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary (?) age.
NarNarrative: This fossil crab has been preserved in the soft mud in which it lived. It is a relative of the mud sentinel crabs that live on the east coast of Australia. The sentinel crabs lie partly buried in soft mud in estuaries and on muddy coasts. They have tall eyestalks that appear above the water surface to look out for predators. The crab extracts food particles out of the mud that it eats.
ComName_tab: Crab, macropthalmus latreillei, Animalia Invertebrata Arthropoda Crustacea
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Arthropoda & Crustacea : : : :

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil crustacean (lobster), a Mud Lobster, Thalassina anomala, collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary (?) age.
NarNarrative: Mud lobsters are common today in tropical regions along muddy shorelines and in mangrove swamps. They burrow in the mud and recycle organic matter from deep underground and are an important part of the mangrove ecosystem. They build volcano-like mounds up to 3m high which provide habitats for a variety of plants and animals. Mud lobsters are a pest in areas where prawn or fish farming occurs. They are edible but have a muddy flavour and are not popular.
ComName_tab: Mud Lobster, thalassina anomala (herbst), Animalia Invertebrata Arthropoda Crustacea
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Arthropoda & Crustacea : : : :

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil annelid (worm tube), Serpula sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary (?) age.
NarNarrative: The soft bodies of worms are not usually preserved as fossils. All that is usually left is the hard calcareous (made of calcite) tubes that the worms live inside. Serpula belongs to the same family as earthworms and lived in a similar way burrowing through sediment on the sea floor. It fed on food particles found in the sediment. They often occur in great numbers and were an important part of the food chain in most seafloor communities.
ComName_tab: Worm Tube, serpula sp., Animalia Invertebrata Vermes Polychaetae
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Vermes & Polychaetae : : : : Annelida

ColPhysicalDescription: Secimen of a fossil gastropod (snail), Crommium augustatum, collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary (?) age.
NarNarrative: The thick, smooth shell of this fossil sea snail has well-developed growth lines. The thick, strong shell suggests that Crommium lived in a high energy (rough water) coastal area. The snail was a predator and moved around on the sea floor searching for other shell-fish to feed on.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Mactromya arenacea, collected from the Lower Lias rocks of Early Jurassic age at Blockley, Gloucestershire. Collected by D.M. Lumsden.
NarNarrative: Mactromya arenacea was a bivalve (meaning two shells or valves)that lived buried in soft mud. This bivalve would have got its food by filtering sea water through a long siphon that passed from its shells and up out of its burrow, where the current would have allowed food particles in the sea water to enter the siphon. Waste materials were passed out through a second siphon.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil ammonite, Dactylioceras commune, collected from Upper Lias rocks of Commune Sub-zone, Early Jurassic age. The ammonite has the head of a snake carved at the end of the shell.
NarNarrative: This ammonite has the head of a snake carved at the end of the shell. Ammonites like this one are known as 'snakestones'. Legend has it that ammonites are the remains of snakes that were turned to stone by St. Hilda, on the site where she was building a convent in Whitby. Because there were no heads on these fossils, the local dealers and collector's often carved heads on the ammonites to increase sales.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Ammonoidea : : : Cephalopoda : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil ammonite, Dactylioceras commune, collected from Upper Lias rocks of Commune Sub-zone, Early Jurassic age.
NarNarrative: Dactylioceras commune is an ammonite that is commonly found on the Yorkshire coast. This is the same kind of ammonite as the snakestone, also in this case, so that you can see what it would have looked like before the snake's head was carved on it. The ribs of Dactylioceras start as a single line and then split into pairs over the edge (keel) of the ammonite, and then turn back to a single line. This is called 'bifurcation'. These rib patterns are often used to tell different species of ammonites apart.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Ammonoidea : : : Cephalopoda : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil ammonite, Hildoceras bifrons, collected from Upper Lias rocks of Bifrons Zone, Early Jurassic age.
NarNarrative: This common ammonite is often found on the Yorkshire coast. Ammonites were often used to make snakestones. If you look very closely at the shell, you can see the suture lines, which in this case are a pale beige colour. Suture lines mark the boundaries between the different chambers in the shell, and in this case, the lines look quite frilly, like a piece of lace.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Ammonoidea : : : Cephalopoda : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil gastropod (snail), a Portland Screw, Aptyxiella portlandica, probably collected from the Portland Stone of Late Jurassic, Tithonian age from Dorset (SW England).
NarNarrative: This gastropod (snail shell) fossil is interesting, because it shows us what the inside of this shell looked like. Usually, we only see the outside of the shell. The shell of this fossil has dissolved away, and we can see the rock inside the shell. Fossils of the insides of long, pointed gastropods like this one are called screwstones.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, a Devil's Toenail, Gryphaea sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Jurassic (?) age.
NarNarrative: This large Gryphaea shell is a very good example of a 'Devil's toenail', as these fossils are sometimes called. Gryphaea is a relative of the modern oyster, and is also related to clams and mussels. The difference though, is that the two shells of the Gryphaea have very different shapes. The thinner outer shell is large and curved with a very rough, flaky surface, like a neglected toenail. The smaller, flat shell is very thick.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil ammonite, Dactylioceras commune, collected from Upper Lias rocks of Commune Sub-zone, Jurassic age.
NarNarrative: The shell of this ammonite has been replaced by iron pyrite (fool's gold), which gives it a brassy, slightly metallic appearance. The shells of fossils can be replaced by all sorts of different minerals, some of the more common ones are calcite, quartz and opal. The type of mineral that replaces a fossil shell depends on the type of rock in which the fossil forms, and the conditions it is subjected to while it is buried in the earth's crust.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Ammonoidea : : : Cephalopoda : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil crinoid (Sea Lily), Cyathocrinites sp., collected from the Ford Formation (reef facies) of Late Permian, Zechstein (Durham Province), EZ1 age from Sunderland (?), Tyne and Wear (NE England).
NarNarrative: Crinoids are a group of sea creatures that are still alive today. The majority of crinoids attach themselves to the sea-floor, and have a long, flexible 'stem', with a crown of tentacles at the top. Although crinoids look like plants (which is why they are also known as sea-lilies), they are animals that feed on tiny creatures (plankton). Broken fragments of crinoid stems make up this fossil.
SciName: Crinoidea : : : : Echinodermata
LocalSum: UK, England, Tyne and Wear (NE England), Sunderland (?)

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil echinoid (sea urchin), Micraster sp., collected from the Chalk Formation (?) of Late Cretaceous age.
NarNarrative: Micraster is a heart-shaped sea urchin. This one is white, because it is preserved in chalk, a very pure form of limestone. Fossils like this one have been called Fairy loaves, because it was thought that if a family kept some of these fossils in the house, they would not go short of bread.
SciName: Echinoidea : : : : Echinodermata

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil echinoid (sea urchin), Micraster sp., collected from the Chalk Formation (?) of Late Cretaceous age.
NarNarrative: Micraster is a heart-shaped sea urchin. Fossils of this type have been described as Fairy loaves, because they were shaped a bit like loaves of bread. Keeping them in the house was thought to prevent the family from going short of bread. In parts of Southern England, fossil sea urchins were thought to prevent milk going sour, and were sometimes kept in dairies for this reason.
SciName: Echinoidea : : : : Echinodermata

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil gastropod, Yunnania tunstallensis, collected from the Ford Formation (reef facies) of Late Permian, Zechstein (Durham Province), EZ1 age from Sunderland (?), Tyne and Wear (NE England).
NarNarrative: Yunnania tunstallensis is a tiny gastropod (sea snail) that looks a bit like a periwinkle. This shell fish lived on a tropical reef, a large underwater colony, teeming with life, in the warm waters of the Zechstein Sea 250 million years ago. This sea stetched between what is now northern England and Poland. Fossils of this type can be found in rocks of Permian age near Sunderland.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, Tyne and Wear (NE England), Sunderland (?)

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimens of fossil crinoids (sea lilies), collected from unspecified rocks of Carboniferous (?) age.
NarNarrative: This piece of limestone has lots of fossil crinoid stem pieces in it. Crinoid fossils are very common in the Carboniferous limestones of north east England. Pebbles of black limestone found on local beaches sometimes contain pale grey or white sections of crinoid stems that can look like rows of teeth. Because crinoid stems are hollow, they become filled up with sediment when they are fossilised. The teeth-like fossils are revealed when rocks are weathered (worn away by water action), into pebbles.
SciName: Crinoidea : : : : Echinodermata

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil echinoid (sea urchin), unidentified, collected from unspecified rocks of Late (?) Cretaceous age.
NarNarrative: This is a fossil sea urchin that has been replaced by flint. Flint fossils are usually found in chalk, a soft white rock that is not found in north east England. Even so, fossils like this one, often badly damaged, are sometimes found on our sea shore. Ships that took coal from Newcastle to London were filled up with stones and sand (ballast) from the beaches of southern England for their journey back to Newcastle. This ballast contained a lot of flint, and was dumped off the North East coast, so that the ships could take on a new cargo of coal.
SciName: Echinoidea : : : : Echinodermata

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil trace fossil, unidentified, collected from unspecified rocks.
NarNarrative: The snake-shaped marking on this piece of sandstone is known as a trace fossil. It is a mark made by an animal, hundreds of millions of years ago, on wet sand, before the sand became rock. We don't know which animal made this mark, but its shape suggests that it may have been a fish, eel or worm-like creature.

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil trace fossil, unidentified, collected from unspecified rocks.
NarNarrative: These two parallel (side by side) snake shaped markings on this piece of sandstone are known as trace fossils, meaning that they are marks made on a piece of rock before it hardened. These were possibly made by a fish, worm or eel-like creature. Unfortunately, we don't know how old this piece of rock is, or where it came from.

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a trace fossil, collected from unspecified rocks.
NarNarrative: This slab of sandstone is covered with narrow, winding marks. These are the fossilised tracks made by small animals, as they crawled across wet sand. We don't know what kind of animal made the tracks. If you look closely, you might see that there is a groove down the middle of these tracks, which may have been made by a tail. Fossils like these are called trace fossils.

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil brachiopod, unidentified, collected from unspecified rocks.
NarNarrative: Brachiopods are sometimes called 'lamp shells' because the shape of some brachiopods, such as this one, is very similar to that of Roman terracotta lamps (also shown). If you compare the shape of the lamp and the fossilised brachiopod, the general shape of both is very similar. The brachiopod has a hole at the top (the pointed end) like the lamp. In the lamp, this is where a wick (like a candlewick) would be inserted. The lamp is hollow, like the shell.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Brachiopoda & Articulata : : : Articulata : Brachiopoda

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Myophorella incurva, collected from the Portland Stone of Late Jurassic, Portlandian age from (?), Dorset (SW England).
NarNarrative: This is an internal cast (showing what the inside of the shell looked like), of the bivalve Myophorella incurva. The shells have been dissolved away, leaving a fossil of the inner surface of the shells. Robert Plot, writing in the 17th century, compared these common fossils to horses heads, with large eyes, ears, and a mane. In Dorset, the local dialect translates 'horses heads' into 'osses 'eds.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Arctica morrisi, collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary, Eocene age.
NarNarrative: This bivalve (meaning two shells), is similar to Myophorella incurva, the one that looks a bit like a horse's head. This bivalve shows the outside of the shell, while the one like the horse's head is of the inside of the shell. When they were alive, shellfish of this kind would have lived buried in the mud of the sea floor. We usually find just the outsides of bivalve shells as fossils.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil gastropod, Scaphella (?) & sp., collected from the Red Crag (?) of Tertiary, Early (?) Pleistocene age.
NarNarrative: The fossil on the right is an internal cast (from the inside of the shell), of a gastropod (sea snail) shell. It is similar to the modern shell that is shown on the left. Living gastropods of this type feed on bivalve shells by making a neat hole in the shell of their victim, through which they suck out its body. Internal casts show us what the inside of a fossil shell looked like. These fossils are less common than the ones that show what the outside of a shell looks like.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil trilobite, unidentified, collected from unspecified rocks.
NarNarrative: This is a fossil of a trilobite, an animal that looked a bit like a woodlouse. Their bodies are divided into three sections, the head, thorax (middle part of the body), and tail (pygidium). It is more common to find only one of these parts of a trilobite, rather than the whole animal, because trilobites shed their outer skeletons in order to grow. Trilobites spent their lives at the bottom of the sea, using their many legs to crawl over the sea floor.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Arthropoda & Trilobita : : : :

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil trilobite, unidentified, collected from unspecified rocks.
NarNarrative: This is a fossil trilobite in a piece of slate. The trilobite was buried in mud, which then became a layered rock called shale. Heat and pressure, over hundreds of millions of years, turned the shale into slate, a much stronger type of rock. At the same time, the trilobite was twisted and squashed.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Arthropoda & Trilobita : : : :

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Spondylus spinosus, possibly collected from the Chalk Formation of Late Cretaceous age.
NarNarrative: This spiny bivalve shell has been preserved in a flint nodule. Flint nodules often form around the remains of dead animals. The material that forms flint (silica...the same material from which glass is made) is dissolved in the sea water. Spondylus spinosus lived on the seabed, where it used the spines on its shell to help support its weight and keep it firmly on the sea floor.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil echinoid (sea urchin), unidentified, collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary age.
NarNarrative: This flattened sea urchin lived on a sandy sea floor. It has a thick test (skeleton), which shows that it lived in a high-energy (rough water) environment. Living Clypeasters are found in coastal areas below the low tide mark. In life, the test was covered with skin and spines that it used to help it burrow. It fed by eating sand and extracting tiny food particles out of it.
SciName: Echinoidea : : : : Echinodermata

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Artica islandica, collected from unspecified rocks of Quaternary (?) age.
NarNarrative: This common round bivalve has equally sized shells covered with growth lines. It lived in a vertical position in a shallow burrow on sandy and other types of seabed sediments. The shells have remained together suggests that the bivalve remained undisturbed in its burrow after it died. Artica lived in shallow coastal water including the intertidal zone and fed on microscopic food particles that it filtered out of the water.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil coral, Palaeosmilia sp., collected from the Carboniferous Limestone (?) of Early (?) Carboniferous, Dinantian (?), Visean (?) age from Ironbridge, Shropshire (Midland England).
NarNarrative: This is the horn-shaped skeleton of a solitary coral (one that doesn't share a skeleton structure with other corals). Palaeosmilia was attached to the sea floor at the pointed end. The living coral polyp occupied the cup shaped hollow at the wide end of the horn. The polyp looked like a sea anemone with a mouth in the centre of a ring of tentacles that it used to capture small animals as food. Like most corals it lived in warm shallow seas near the equator and may have been part of a reef community.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata &  Anthozoa : : : : Coelenterata

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil blastoid, Pentremites sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Early (?) Carboniferous, Mississippian (?) age.
NarNarrative: Pentramites is one of the best known Blastoids, an extinct group of echinoderms (a group that includes star fish and sea urchins). The bud-shaped calyx (cup) has five-sided symmetry (hence the name "pent...") and contained the animal's organs. It was attached to the sea floor by a stalk and had a crown of delicate arms that it used to collect food particles. The mouth is in the centre surrounded by five circular holes known as spiracles, one of which contains the anus. Blastoids usually lived in shallow water reefs.
SciName: Blastoidea : : : : Echinodermata

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil blastoid, Pentremites pyriformis, collected from unspecified rocks of Early (?) Carboniferous, Mississippian (?) age from Indiana, USA. Collected by David M. Lumsden.
NarNarrative: Pentramites is one of the best known Blastoids, an extinct group of echinoderms (a group that includes star fish and sea urchins). The bud-shaped calyx (cup) has five-sided symmetry (hence the name "pent...") and contained the animal's organs. It was attached to the sea floor by a stalk and had a crown of delicate arms that it used to collect food particles. The mouth is in the centre surrounded by five circular holes known as spiracles, one of which contains the anus. Blastoids usually lived in shallow water reefs.
SciName: Blastoidea : : : : Echinodermata

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil graptolite, Phyllograptus angustifolius, collected from unspecified rocks of Ordovician, Arenig age.
NarNarrative: Graptolites were microscopic animals which lived in the sea. Their skeletons are made from a mineral called chitin, and shaped into a series of very small tubes that are joined together. Graptolites lived near the surface of the sea supported by floats. When they died the skeletons sank to the seabed and became fossilised. The fossilised remains of Graptolites are common in rocks of Ordovician and Silurian age but they became extinct at the end of the Carboniferous period.
ComName_tab: , phyllograptus angustifolius, Animalia Chordata Hemichordata Graptolithina
SciName: Animalia & Chordata & Hemichordata & Graptolithina : : : :

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil trilobite, Calymene sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Silurian (?) age.
NarNarrative: These animals are called Trilobites because the jointed shells which protected their bodies are divided into three parts. These three parts are shown very well in this specimen. It has a well-developed head and a middle section called a thorax. This consists of a series of flexible plates. It also has a well-developed 'tail' called a pygidium that consists of a series of plates that are fused together. Trilobites like this one are thought to have crawled across the seabed scavenging for food.
ComName_tab: , calymene sp., Animalia Invertebrata Arthropoda Trilobita
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Arthropoda & Trilobita : : : :

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil graptolite, Didymograptus sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Ordovician, Arenig - Llanvirn (Llandelian) age.
NarNarrative: At first sight Graptolites like these look like tiny fossilised saw blades. In fact each tiny 'saw tooth' represents the end of a tube where a minute sea creature used to live. The complete skeletons were made by colonies of these animals, drifting in the surface waters of the Ordovician sea. Didymograptus is often called the 'Tuning Fork' graptolite because of the overall forked appearance of the skeleton. The pointed end at the top of the 'fork' would have been attached to some sort of float allowing the rest of the skeleton to hang down in the water. After death the skeletons of these graptolites sank to the seabed in large numbers to be covered in sediment and fossilised.
ComName_tab: , didymograptus sp., Animalia Chordata Hemichordata Graptolithina
SciName: Animalia & Chordata & Hemichordata & Graptolithina : : : :

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil trilobite, Angelina sedgwicki Salter, collected from unspecified rocks of Ordovician, Tremadoc age.
NarNarrative: Trilobites were marine animals which lived in the sea. This particular example probably crawled over the seabed scavenging for food. After death it became buried in the mud on the seabed which eventually turned into mudstone. As continents collided the rock was squeezed and heated and turned into slate. This is why the fossil looks a little lop-sided and pushed out of shape.
ComName_tab: , angelina sedgwickii (salter), Animalia Invertebrata Arthropoda Trilobita
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Arthropoda & Trilobita : : : :

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil brachiopod, Lingulella davisi, collected from unspecified rocks of Late Cambrian age.
NarNarrative: Lingulella is of great interest because it is very similar to a living brachiopod called Lingula. Lingula lives in burrows and can be found in the Pacific Ocean. It is a good example of a 'Living Fossil', which is a plant or animal fossil that has not become extinct.
ComName_tab: Lamp Shell, lingulella davisi (m'coy), Animalia Invertebrata Brachiopoda Inarticulata
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Brachiopoda & Inarticulata : : : :

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil trilobite, Anaspis stokesi, collected from unspecified rocks of Silurian, Wenlock age.
NarNarrative: Trilobites have a segmented body and look very similar to giant woodlice. They were marine animals that usually crawled on the seabed, scavenging for food.
ComName_tab: , anaspis stokesi, Animalia Invertebrata Arthropoda Trilobita
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Arthropoda & Trilobita : : : :

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil cephalopod, Orthoceras bullatus, collected from unspecified rocks of Silurian (?) age.
NarNarrative: An animal distantly related to the modern squid and Nautilus once lived in this shell. The complete shell would have been cone-shaped and divided up into a series of hollow air chambers. Some of these chambers are clearly visible on the fossil as a series of straight lines. In life, the air chambers would have enabled the animal to float in mid-water and hunt for food. After death, the shell sank to the seabed, the animal rotted away, and the air chambers filled with mud which later hardened into rock.
ComName_tab: , orthoceras bullatus, Animalia Invertebrata Mollusca Cephalopoda Nautiloidea
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Nautiloidea : : : :

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil assemblage, unidentified, collected from the Much Wenlock Limestone Formation of Silurian, Wenlock, Homerian age from Wren's Nest (?), Dudley, West Midlands (Midland England).
NarNarrative: This limestone is a piece of fossilised seabed. It is packed with hundreds of fossil animals including branching skeletons of bryozoa (moss animals), corals, brachiopods (lamp shells), and fragments of trilobites. This shows that during the Silurian period, Dudley was covered by a shallow sunlit tropical sea crowded with many different kinds of animals.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata : : : :
LocalSum: UK, England, West Midlands (Midland England), Dudley, Wren's Nest

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil trilobite, a Dudley Locust, Calymene blumenbachi, collected from the Much Wenlock Limestone Formation of Silurian, Wenlock, Homerian age from Wren's Nest, Dudley, West Midlands (Midland England).
NarNarrative: This beautifully preserved trilobite was a very common fossil in the Silurian Limestones quarried at Dudley in the 18th and 19th centuries. It was much prized by collector's and became famously known as the Dudley Locust. It even appears on the Dudley Coat of Arms.
ComName_tab: Dudley Locust, calymene blumenbachi (brongniart 1822), Animalia Invertebrata Arthropoda Trilobita
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Arthropoda & Trilobita : : : :
LocalSum: UK, England, West Midlands (Midland England), Dudley, Wren's Nest

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil cephalopod, Nautilus sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary (?) age from Morroco (?), Africa.
NarNarrative: The spirally coiled shell of this fossil Nautilus has been dissolved away to show the inside structure made of septa (walls) and chambers. The animal lived in the outermost chamber of the shell and the smaller chambers were filled with gas. This made Nautilus buoyant and allowed it to adjust its position in the water by varying the amount of gas in its shell. Nautilus swam using jet propulsion, forcing water out of its body. They were carnivores and fed mainly on shrimps, crabs and fish caught in their tentacles.
ComName_tab: , nautilus sp., Animalia Invertebrata Mollusca Cephalopoda Nautiloidea
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Nautiloidea : : : :
ColSum: Johnson, Eric (stratigraphy revised based on information in record)

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil goniatite, Muensteroceras redesdalense Philips, collected from the Redesdale Ironstone, Scremerston Coal Group of Early Carboniferous, Dinantian, Visean, Asbian age from Ridsdale, Northumberland (NE England). Collected by Richard Howse.
NarNarrative: Gonatites were similar to the coiled-shelled ammonites but more primitive. The inside of the shell was divided up by septa (walls) into several separate chambers. The animal was similar to a squid and lived in the outermost chamber and the smaller chambers were filled with gas so that the shell was buoyant. Muensteroceras lived near the surface of the sea and swam using jet propulsion, forcing water out of its body. It was carnivores and fed mainly on shrimps, crabs and fish they caught in their tentacles.
ComName_tab: , muensteroceras redesdalense (phillips), Animalia Invertebrata Mollusca Cephalopoda
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda : : : :

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil nautiloid, Nautilus sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Early Carboniferous, Dinantian, Visean, Asbian age from Otterburn, Northumberland (NE England).
NarNarrative: The coiled shell has been dissolved away revealing the septa (walls) and chambers of the inside of the shell. The animal lived in the outermost chamber and the smaller chambers were filled with gas. This made Nautilus buoyant and allowed it to adjust its position in the water by varying the volume of gas in its shell (ie less gas makes it sink, more makes it float upwards). Nautilus swam using jet propulsion, forcing water out of its body. They were carnivores and fed mainly on shrimps, crabs and fish. The modern Nautilus is very similar to its fossil ancestors.

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Anthracosia robusta, collected from the Modiolus Zone, Lower Coal Measures, Busty Seam of Late Carboniferous, Westphalian, Langsettian age from Derwent Pit, Medomsley, Co Durham (NE England).
NarNarrative: These mussels lived in shallow, freshwater lakes and brackish (slightly salty) water lagoons that formed when coastal, coal forming forests were flooded. Like present day mussels they lived in large colonies. They formed important 'mussel bands' in Coal Measures rocks and some can be used to identify individual coal seams. The specimen is from the 'mussel band' that occurred in the roof of the Busty Seam.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, Co. Durham (NE England), Medomsley, Derwent Pit

NarNarrative: The thick shell of this slender spindle shaped sea snail is covered with spiral ribs and has a long canal (groove) below the body chamber. The canal provided protection for a siphon (tube) that took water into the snail's body. Fusinus was a scavenger and a predator that fed on dead animals and living bivalves that lived on the seabed. It was part of a community of animals living in a shallow subtropical sea.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, Hampshire (SE England), Bournemouth (nr.), Barton

NarNarrative: Crabs are well known crustaceans found in a variety of shallow coastal environments. Their tough exoskeleton (outer shell) is made out of chitin, a material similar to finger nails. They are predators and scavengers that feed on bivalves and gastropods that they break open with their claws. Crabs are fairly common fossils particularly in Tertiary sedimentary rocks. The specimen shows the underside of the crab, including parts of the legs and claws.

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil graptolite, Dicranograptus clingani, collected from the Loweswater Formation, Skiddaw Group of Early Ordovician, Arenig, Moridunian age from Barf, Bassenthwaite, Cumbria (NW England). Collected by Emma Smith.
NarNarrative: Graptolites were a group of marine colonial animals that belong to the group Hemichordata (chordates without a backbone). Most of them floated freely about in the ocean, but some lived attached to the bottom. They lived from the Cambrian to the mid-Carboniferous. As fossils, most of the graptolites look like branches of saw blades, with a length from 10 millimetres up to one metre long. They are usually white or silvery against the dark shale. Each 'saw tooth' was a small tube and housed a small animal. The soft parts of the graptolites have never been found, but we assume that the animal fed by extending a wreath of tentacles to capture food particles.
ComName_tab: , dicranograptus clingani, Animalia Chordata Hemichordata Graptolithina
SciName: Animalia & Chordata & Hemichordata & Graptolithina : : : :
LocalSum: UK, England, Cumbria (NW England), Bassenthwaite, Barf

NarNarrative: This is the fossilised shell of a snail which lived on the bed of the Silurian sea. Snails were very important scavengers, feeding mainly on the remains of dead animals. Some snails fed on seaweeds which were probably common in the shallower, sunlit parts of the Silurian Sea.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil trilobite, Dalmanites myops Konig, collected from the Much Wenlock Limestone Formation of Silurian, Wenlock, Homerian age from Dudley, West Midlands (Midland England).
NarNarrative: Trilobites are very common fossils in the Silurian rocks exposed at Dudley. Looking like overgrown woodlice, they probably crawled over the seabed scavenging for food. Trilobites grew by shedding their shells (moulting) and then growing a new one. This means that moulted fragments are more common as fossils than complete shells. This particular example is a tail, or pygidium, of a trilobite, and probably represents part of a moulted shell.
ComName_tab: , dalmanites myops (konig), Animalia Invertebrata Arthropoda Trilobita
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Arthropoda & Trilobita : : : :
LocalSum: UK, England, West Midlands (Midland England), Dudley

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil sponge, unidentified, collected from unspecified rocks of Devonian age from Boulogne, France. Collected by W.K. Loftus (?).
NarNarrative: Sponges are animals that have a very simple structure. They live ina wide range of water depths, and date back to the Cambrian period, 500 million years ago. They usually live in clear water, and feed by drawing water through their outer wall, extracting food from it, and then passing the water out through a larger opening.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Porifera : : : :

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil crinoid (Sea Lily), Actinocrinites sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Middle Devonian age from Eifel, Rhine, Germany. Collected by W.K. Loftus (?). Crinoid calyx.

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil scaphopod (tusk shell), unidentified, collected from unspecified rocks of Middle Devonian age from Eifel, Rhine, Germany. Collected by W.K. Loftus (?).
NarNarrative: Scaphopods, which are also known as tusk shells (because they are shaped like a tusk), are shellfish that live in the sea. This animal lived with the wider end of the shell buried in the seabed, and the narrower end in the water. This example is from rocks of Devonian age, but scaphopods are more common today than they were in the past.
ComName_tab: Tusk Shell, , Animalia Invertebrata Mollusca Scaphopoda
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Scaphopoda : : : :
