ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil gastropod (snail), Murchisonia intermedia, collected from unspecified rocks of Middle Devonian age from Hand, near Paffrath, Germany. Collected by W.K. Loftus.
NarNarrative: Murchisonia intermedia was a gastropod (sea snail) that lived in a tall pointed shell. Gastropods have a muscular foot-like organ, which they use to move around. They feed using their radula (a rough, tongue like organ, made up of many tiny teeth). This gastropod probably spent its life burrowing into the sea floor, in search of food.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil coral, Heliolites porosus, collected from unspecified rocks of Devonian age from ?, Devon (SW England). Collected by William Pengelly.
NarNarrative: Heliolites was a colonial coral (many coral animals living together) that is now extinct. The individual coral animals, also known as polyps, looked a bit like small sea anemones. They lived in tubes made of the mineral calcite, which were joined together to form a colony. In Heliolites, these tubes, called corallites, were separated by smaller tubes that did not contain polyps.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata &  Anthozoa : : : : Coelenterata

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Neithea quinquecostata, collected from the Inflatum Zone = Dispar Zone, Upper Greensand Formation of Cretaceous, Late Albian age from Warminster, Wiltshire (SW England).
NarNarrative: This scallop takes its species name from the five (quin) main ribs(costata) that strengthen the convex (outward curving) shell. The scallop lived on a sandy seabed in shallow coastal waters below. It was able to swim by clapping its two valves together to force out jets of water. It usually only did this to escape from predators such as fish. It fed on tiny food particles that it filtered out of the water.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Coral
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata &  Anthozoa : : : : Coelenterata

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil foraminifera, Loftusia persica Brady, collected from the Lower Tertiary Limestone of Tertiary age from Kellapstun Pass (Bakhtiyari Mountains), Du Pulun (nr.), Iran. Collected by William K. Loftus.
NarNarrative: Foraminifera are sea-living microfossils (microscopic-sized fossils) that secrete a hard calcareous (made of calcite) skeleton known as a test. Loftusia is quite large and has a flat, spirally coiled shell. It lived on the floor of a warm shallow sea, often in such great numbers that the tests later formed limestones like the one shown here. Foraminifera changed (evolved) very quickly through time. This means that they can be used to identify different rocks layers, as distinct species are only found in certain layers.
SciName: Protista & Foraminifera : : : :
LocalSum: Iran, Du Pulun (nr.), Kellapstun Pass (Bakhtiyari Mountains)

ColPhysicalDescription: specimen of a fossil brachiopod lamp shell, Cyrtia exporrecta, collected from the Much Wenlock Limestone Formation of Silurian, Wenlock, Homerian age from Dudley, West Midlands (Midland England). Collected by Emma Smith. With C. epifauna.
NarNarrative: Brachiopods are animals which live in or on the seabed. Although fairly rare in present day seas, their fossilised shells are very common in Silurian rocks and show an amazing variety of different shapes. The animal was protected by two shells hinged at the pointed end. Sometimes, as in this example, the two shells are very different in shape and form. This view of the back of the two shells shows a top shell which is fairly flat but the lower shell has much more of a triangular shape. Such a curious difference of shape suggests a specialised way of life which we can only guess at as this kind of brachiopod became extinct millions of years ago.
ComName_tab: Lamp Shell, cyrtia exporrecta (wahlenberg), Brachiopod Articulata
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Brachiopoda & Articulata : : : Articulata : Brachiopoda
LocalSum: UK, England, West Midlands (Midland England), Dudley

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil brachiopod, Gypidula dudleyensis Schuchert, collected from the Much Wenlock Limestone Formation of Silurian, Wenlock, Homerian age from Dudley, West Midlands (Midland England). Collected by Emma Smith.

SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Brachiopoda & Articulata : : : Articulata : Brachiopoda

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil coral, Labechia conferta Lonsdale, collected from the Much Wenlock Limestone Formation (?) of Silurian, Wenlock, Homerian age from Dudley, West Midlands (Midland England).
NarNarrative: This is the bottom view of a fossilised colonial coral and shows how the colony grew. A single coral animal (polyp) would have settled on the seabed and formed a tiny tube of calcium carbonate in which to live. This forms the pointed part in the middle of the photograph. The animal would have reproduced by a process of budding so that two tubes would have formed. Each of these would have budded again to form four. This process would have been repeated many times over and over again so that eventually a cushion-shaped skeleton consisting of thousands of tubes was formed. When the coral polyps died, the hard calcium carbonate skeleton remained and became part of the limestone rock forming on the seabed. These Silurian limestones underly much of Dudley. They are a rich source of fossil corals and other animals that lived and died in the sunlit tropical Silurian sea.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata &  Anthozoa : : : : Coelenterata
LocalSum: UK, England, West Midlands (Midland England), Dudley

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil gastropod (snail), Euomphalopterus sp., collected from the Much Wenlock Limestone Formation (?) of Silurian, Wenlock, Homerian age.
NarNarrative: These are the fossilised shells of snails which lived on the bed of the Silurian sea. Snails were very important scavengers on the Silurian reefs, feeding mainly on the remains of dead animals. Some snails fed on seaweeds which were also probably common in the shallower, sunlit parts of the Silurian Sea.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil coral, Lonsdaleia floriformis var. laticlavia, collected from the Millstone Grit Group, Great Limestone of Early Carboniferous, Namurian, Pendleian age from Greenleighton, Northumberland (NE England). Collected by Sir W.C. Trevelyan.
NarNarrative: This coral colony is made up of angular corallites (individual coral skeletons) that are in close contact with each other. Each corallite has a well-defined centre (axial column) that looks like a flower and gives the species' its name. A living coral polyp occupied the hollow in each corallite. The polyp was similar to a sea anemone with a mouth in the centre of a ring of tentacles, which it used to capture small animals as food. Like most corals it lived attached to the floor of warm shallow seas near the equator.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata &  Anthozoa : : : : Coelenterata

NarNarrative: This delicate ridged shell is a fossilised brachiopod. If you look closely, you can see a small circular hole near the top of the shell, which has filled up after the animal died and was buried. Through this small hole, a fleshy anchoring 'stem' known as the pedicle protruded, with which the brachiopod anchored itself to a hard surface on the sea floor.

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil gastropod (snail), Purpuroidea morrisea, collected from the Great Oolite of Middle Jurassic, Bathonian age from Minchinhampton, Gloucestershire (SW England). Collected by A.G. Dew-Smith.
NarNarrative: This fossil is a gastropod (sea snail). Gastropods lived inside coiled shells. Purpuroidea crawled over the surface of the seabed, as it searched for food, on a muscular 'foot' that protruded from the hole in its shell. This gastropod is often found in rocks that were formed in areas where the sea floor was unstable. These were conditions that many other animals would not have been able to survive.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve (oyster), Gryphaea dilatata, collected from unspecified rocks of Late Jurassic, Oxfordian age from Buckinghamshire (SE England).
NarNarrative: This fossil, Gryphaea dilatata, is very similar to Gryphaea arcuata, which is also known as the devil's toenail, because it looks a bit like a claw. Gryphaea dilatata has a slightly different shape, which is much wider and shorter. It is also found in rocks that are a little younger than those containing devil's toenails.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil annelid (worm), Lumbricaria sp., collected from the Lithographic Limestone of Late Jurassic age from Solenhofen, Bavaria, Germany.
NarNarrative: The long dark shape on one of these two pieces of rock is a fossil of a worm. The groove on the other piece of rock fits over the top of the worm, because this bit of rock rests on top of the piece that contains the fossil. It is unusual to find a fossilised worm. Fossils of shells and bones are much more common, because they are hard, and don't decay quickly. Soft animals like worms have no hard parts such as bones or shells, and usually decay too quickly to become fossils.

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Radulopecten vagans, collected from unspecified rocks of Jurassic age.
NarNarrative: Radulopecten was a bivalve (meaning two valves or shells) that looked very similar to the modern scallop. This bivalve did not live on, or buried in the seabed, like most of these shell fish. This bivalve was free-swimming, like fish. Modern scallops have a row of eyes on the edge of the mantle, the fleshy material that can be seen between the edges of the open shell, and Radulopecten was probably similar. They move by opening and closing rapidly, forcing water out of the shell and hence pushing themselves backwards.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil ammonite, Stephanoceras eugenii, collected from the Oxford Clay of Late Jurassic, Oxfordian age from St. Ives, Cambridgeshire (SE England).
NarNarrative: Stephanoceras eugenii is an ammonite from the Oxford Clay. The rusty orange colour of this fossil is caused by a high concentration of iron in the rock which it is found in. Ammonites lived in the sea, and were eaten by large marine reptile such as ichthyosaurs, that looked a bit like dolphins. Ammonites were alive at the same time as the dinosaurs, and became extinct at the same time, 65 million years ago.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Ammonoidea : : : Cephalopoda : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil ammonite, Macrocephalites macrocephalus, collected from the Kelloways Rock of Middle Jurassic, Callovian age from Yorkshire (NE England).
NarNarrative: Macrocephalites macrocephalus was an ammonite that lived approximately 160 million years ago. Ammonites lived in the sea, and were probably eaten by the larger animals that lived there, for example, ichthyosaurs, large marine reptiles that looked a bit like dolphins. Ammonites and ichthyosaurs both died out at the same time as the dinosaurs, 65 million years ago. This ammonite has a brassy colour, because its shell has been replaced by the mineral iron pyrite (fool's gold).
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Ammonoidea : : : Cephalopoda : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil nautiloid, Nautilus sp., collected from the Lias of Jurassic age from Yorkshire (NE England).
NarNarrative: Nautilus is related to the modern Pearly Nautilus which lives in the Pacific Ocean today. On the surface of this fossil, the suture lines, which mark the growth stages of the animal, can be clearly seen. The suture line of Nautilus is much simpler than that of the ammonites, for example, Phylloceras and Hildoceras. This fossil was found in Lower Jurassic rocks in Yorkshire.
ComName_tab: , nautilus sp., Animalia Invertebrata Mollusca Cephalopoda Nautiloidea
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Nautiloidea : : : :

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil ammonite, Kosmoceras phaeinum, collected from unspecified rocks of Late Jurassic, Callovian age.
NarNarrative: Kosmoceras phaeinum was an ammonite that lived approximately 160 million years ago. Although ammonites became extinct 65 million years ago, the same time as the dinosaurs, they probably looked very similar to the modern Nautilus that lives in the Pacific Ocean. This ammonite is unusal because it has lappets (thin rectangular projections) on its shell. You can only see one lappet (there would have been two).
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Ammonoidea : : : Cephalopoda : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil ammonite, Hildoceras bifrons, collected from the Bifrons Zone, Upper Lias of Early Jurassic age.
NarNarrative: Hildoceras bifrons was an ammonite that lived during the early Jurassic period, approximately 200 million years ago. If you look closely, you will see that this fossil has some very fine lace-like white markings on its surface. These marks are known as suture lines. Suture lines mark the growth stages of the ammonite shell, and are formed where walls inside the shell meet the side of the shell. Frilly lines like these are only seen on the shells of ammonites. Ammonites such as these are often known as snake-stones because they look a little like a coiled snake. In fact many people have, in the past, even carved snake-like heads onto them.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Ammonoidea : : : Cephalopoda : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Ammonite. Walcottii.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Ammonoidea : : : Cephalopoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, Yorkshire (NE England), Whitby (nr.), Port Mulgrave

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil ammonite, Pleuroceras hawskerense, collected from the Spinatum Zone, Middle Lias of Early Jurassic, Late Pliensbachian age from North Yorkshire (NE England). Collected by Emma Smith. Shows suture pattern.
NarNarrative: Pleuroceras hawskerense was an ammonite that lived during the early Jurassic, approximately 195 million years ago. This ammonite has a frilly suture line, which can be seen on part of the shell. Suture lines are related to the growth of the ammonite, and form where the inner walls of the shell join the side of the shell. Different species of ammonites occur in different layers of rock and are used to date the rocks in which they are found. Such fossils are known as Zone Fossils.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Ammonoidea : : : Cephalopoda : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil ammonite, Rasenia involuta, collected from the Cymodoce Zone, Lower Kimmeridgian rocks of Late Jurassic age.
NarNarrative: Rasenia involuta is from the Cymodoce Zone of the Jurassic rocks (about 144 million years ago). Ammonites are varied fossils, and they evolved (changed over time) quickly. For these reasons, they are used to divide the rocks of the Jurassic period up into time sections or zones. Each of these zones is named after an ammonite that is common in that section of Jurassic rock.
SciName: Rasenia involuta : : : Cephalopoda : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Good specimen showing external ornament and suture pattern.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Ammonoidea : : : Cephalopoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, Dorset (SW England), Burton Cliff, Bridport

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil ammonite, Phylloceras heterophyllum, collected from the Jet Rock Formation, Upper Lias of Early Jurassic age from Whitby, Yorkshire (NE England). Fine specimen showing suture pattern.
NarNarrative: This ammonite has a very simply shaped shell, compared with other ammonites such as Dactilyoceras and Hildoceras, which have shells that are more coiled. If you look closely, you can see the suture lines that cover the surface of the shell, which look a bit like the frilly patterns in a piece of lace. The suture lines form as the shell of the ammonite grows.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Ammonoidea : : : Cephalopoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, North Yorkshire (NE England), Whitby (nr.)

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil ammonite, Oppelia sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Middle Jurassic age.
NarNarrative: Oppelia was an ammonite that was alive at the same time as the dinosaurs, during the Jurassic, and was probably eaten by ichthyosaurs, the large marine reptiles that looked a bit like dolphins. On a part of the shell of this ammonite, traces of the frilly suture lines can be seen. The suture lines are formed where the internal walls of the shell, which are related to the growth of the ammonite, meet the outer shell.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Ammonoidea : : : Cephalopoda : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil nautiloid, Cenoceras sp., collected from the Lias of Early Jurassic age.
NarNarrative: Cenoceras was a nautiloid, a sea creature that is related to the modern Pearly Nautilus that lives in the warm waters of the Pacific Ocean. It would have had tentacles, and swum through the sea looking for small animals to eat. The shell of Cenoceras is similar to the shells of ammonites. The main difference between the shells of ammonites and nautiloids is the suture lines, which are formed where the walls of the inner growth chambers meet the shell. In ammonites, these are usually quite frilly, like a piece of lace. In nautiloids, like this one, they have more of a smooth, curved shape.
ComName_tab: , cenoceras sp., Animalia Invertebrata Mollusca Cephalopoda Nautiloidea
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Nautiloidea : : : :

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil crustacean (crab), unidentified, collected from the Thames Group, London Clay Formation (?) of Tertiary, Early Eocene, Ypresian age. Collected by J. Goring.
NarNarrative: Crabs are found in shallow, coastal waters in a variety of different environments, especially rocky shorelines. Their tough exoskeleton (external shell) is made out of chitin, a substance similar to finger nails. They are predators and feed mainly on bivalves and gastropods that they break open with their claws. This specimen shows a well-preserved body carapace (shell) with claws and legs.
ComName_tab: Unidentified Crab, , Animalia Invertebrata Arthropoda Crustacea
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Arthropoda & Crustacea : : : :

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil ammonite, Rasenia involuta, collected from the Lower Kimmeridgian rocks of Late Jurassic age from Market Rasen, Lincolnshire (Midland England). Collected by R. Howse.
NarNarrative: Rasenia involuta, an ammonite from Market Rasen, Lincolnshire. This ammonite has been named after one of the places where it is commonly found. Fossils are also sometimes named after people, or given a descriptive name which describes their appearance. This ammonite has been replaced by iron pyrite (fool's gold), with irridescent colours (like a shiny blue butterfly wing), including pink, green and blue.
SciName: Rasenia involuta : : : Cephalopoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, Lincolnshire (Midland England), Market Rasen

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil ammonite, Skolekostephanus skolex, collected from unspecified rocks of Middle Jurassic age from Bridport, Dorset (SW England). Collected by G. Ruppell.
NarNarrative: Ammonites are found in all different sizes. Some are only a few millimetres across, while others are more than a metre wide. Ammonites died out at the same time as the dinosaurs, 65 million years ago. They looked a bit like the modern Nautilus that lives in the Pacific Ocean. Ammonites used a jet propulsion system to help them move around. By squirting a jet of water from their shell, they could move backwards very quickly.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Ammonoidea : : : Cephalopoda : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil echinoid (sea urchin), Conulus albogalerus Leske, collected from the Cortestudinarium Zone = Mucronata Zone, Upper Chalk Formation of Late Cretaceous, Senonian age.
NarNarrative: This sea urchin takes its name from its cone shaped test (skeleton). In life, the test was covered with skin and short bristle like spines that helped the echinoid burrow. The smooth shape shows the sea urchin burrowed in soft seabed sediments. It lived in an open sea environment where the salinity (salt content) of the sea water was normal and fed on food particles found in sediments that it ate. Its mouth is on the flattened lower surface.
SciName: Echinoidea : : : : Echinodermata

NarNarrative: This mass of tube-shaped coral skeletons is part of the colonial coral Lithostrotion (a group of corals living together). A living coral polyp would have occupied a cup shaped hollow at the top of each tube. The polyp looked like a sea anemone with a mouth in the centre of a ring of tentacles that it used to capture small animals as food. Like most corals it lived on the floor of warm shallow seas near the equator.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata &  Anthozoa : : : : Coelenterata
LocalSum: UK, England, Co. Durham (NE England), Frosterley (nr.)

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Pecten sp., collected from the Red Crag (?) of Tertiary, Early (?) Pleistocene age. Encrusted with barnacles and serpulids.
NarNarrative: The barnacle and worm tube are cemented (glued) onto the large flat scallop shell. The scallop probably died and its two shells separated before the other animals became attached to it. The tubes on the shell were made by a Serpula worm to provide protection for its soft body on the seafloor. Barnacles are a special type of crustacean (related to crabs and lobsters) that can live on the rocks on the sea shore.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bryozoan (sea mat or moss animal), Retepora cellulosa, collected from the Red Crag of Quaternary, Early Pleistocene age from Suffolk (SE England).
NarNarrative: The skeleton of this Bryozoan (moss animal) colony consists of joined tubes that were built by the thousands of microscopic animals (zooids) that lived in it. A close look at the tubes reveals small holes (cysts) where the soft-bodied zooids lived. The zooids fed on tiny single-celled plants that they caught with their tentacles. The colony probably lived in a low energy shallow water environment at depths between 20 and 80m where its food supply was most abundant.
ComName_tab: Sea Mat (or Moss Animal), retepora cellulosa (johnston), Animalia Invertebrata Bryozoa
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Bryozoa : : : :

NarNarrative: This heart-shaped fossil sea urchin is a typical burrowing echinoid. It has a smooth shell and streamlined shape which allowed it to burrow through soft seabed sediments for its food. Its burrow also provided protection from predators and prevented it being moved by seafloor currents.
SciName: Echinoidea : : : : Echinodermata

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil brachiopod, Harknesella vespertilio Sowerby, collected from unspecified rocks of Middle Ordovician, Caradoc age from Grafton (?), Shropshire (Midland England).
NarNarrative: There are many different kinds of brachiopod (lamp shell) fossils in this siltstone. This suggests that many brachiopods lived and died over a period of time and their shells formed an important part of the sediment deposited on the seabed. The largest fan-shaped shell (towards the left side of the rock) is called Harknesella. At some time after the brachiopods had become fossilised, their shells were dissolved away so that their impressions (moulds) are all that remain in the rock.
ComName_tab: Lamp Shell, harknessella vespertilio, Brachiopod Articulata
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Brachiopoda & Articulata : : : Articulata : Brachiopoda

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil ammonite, Harpoceras sp., collected from the Alum Shale of Early Jurassic age from Yorkshire (NE England). Collected by Emma Smith.
NarNarrative: The shell of this ammonite, Harpoceras, has been partly replaced by iron pyrite (fool's gold), which gives the fossil a slightly brassy or metallic appearance. The ammonite, which looks a bit like a ram's horn, has a very distinctive 'v' shaped pattern on its surface. Ammonites get their name from the Egyptian god Amun. Amun was later portrayed by the Greeks as a ram with curling horns.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Ammonoidea : : : Cephalopoda : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Anadara idonea, collected from the St. Marys Formation of Tertiary, Miocene age from St. Marys River, Maryland, USA. Collected by David M. Lumsden.
NarNarrative: The single, thick shell of this fossil bivalve is covered with coarse ribs. Anodara lived in a shallow burrow on a sandy seabed in a shallow water environment. It had leathery tubes (siphons) that it extended up to the seabed surface, which it used to pump water through its body and filter out tiny food particles.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, unidentified, collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary (?) age.
NarNarrative: This group of bivalve shells is known as a 'death assemblage'. We know this, because the shells are all lying different ways up. The reason for this is that after they died, the shells were moved by currents to an area on the sea floor and were then buried under layers of mud, which hardened and turned into rock. If this was a 'life assemblage' we would expect to see the animals lying as they were when they were alive, having been buried alive by some catastrophic event such as an underwater earthquake.
